15 | # export SYSTEMD_PAGER=

21 |             . "$rc"
22 |         fi

26 | 
27 | . "$HOME/.atuin/bin/env"

30 | eval "$(atuin init bash)"

<file><path>scripts/core_setup.sh</path>
<content lines="1-198">
  1 | #!/bin/bash
  2 | # =============================================================================
  3 | # core_setup.sh - Core system setup: packages, shell, fonts, dotfiles
  4 | # =============================================================================
  5 | 
  6 | set -e
  7 | 
  8 | # Source common utilities
  9 | SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
 10 | source "$SCRIPT_DIR/common.sh"
 11 | 
 12 | check_not_root
 13 | verify_backup_dir
 14 | 
 15 | # =============================================================================
 16 | # System Update
 17 | # =============================================================================
 18 | log_section "Updating system..."
 19 | sudo dnf update -y
 20 | log_success "System updated"
 21 | 
 22 | # =============================================================================
 23 | # Install Core Packages
 24 | # =============================================================================
 25 | log_section "Installing core packages..."
 26 | 
 27 | CORE_PACKAGES=(
 28 |     zsh
 29 |     git
 30 |     curl
 31 |     wget
 32 |     util-linux-user
 33 |     fastfetch
 34 |     kitty
 35 |     podman
 36 |     podman-compose
 37 |     tmux
 38 | )
 39 | 
 40 | dnf_install "${CORE_PACKAGES[@]}"
 41 | log_success "Core packages installed"
 42 | 
 43 | # =============================================================================
 44 | # Install Starship
 45 | # =============================================================================
 46 | log_section "Installing Starship..."
 47 | if dnf_install starship 2>/dev/null; then
 48 |     log_success "Starship installed via dnf"
 49 | else
 50 |     log_warn "Starship not in repos, installing via official script..."
 51 |     curl -sS https://starship.rs/install.sh | sh -s -- -y
 52 |     log_success "Starship installed via official script"
 53 | fi
 54 | 
 55 | # =============================================================================
 56 | # Install Atuin
 57 | # =============================================================================
 58 | log_section "Installing Atuin..."
 59 | if dnf_install atuin 2>/dev/null; then
 60 |     log_success "Atuin installed via dnf"
 61 | else
 62 |     log_warn "Atuin not in repos, installing via official script..."
 63 |     curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://setup.atuin.sh | bash
 64 |     log_success "Atuin installed via official script"
 65 | fi
 66 | 
 67 | # =============================================================================
 68 | # Install Zsh Plugins
 69 | # =============================================================================
 70 | log_section "Installing Zsh plugins..."
 71 | dnf_install zsh-autosuggestions zsh-syntax-highlighting
 72 | log_success "zsh-autosuggestions and zsh-syntax-highlighting installed"
 73 | 
 74 | # zsh-autocomplete
 75 | ZSH_AUTOCOMPLETE_SYSTEM="/usr/share/zsh-autocomplete/zsh-autocomplete.plugin.zsh"
 76 | ZSH_AUTOCOMPLETE_LOCAL="$HOME/.local/share/zsh/plugins/zsh-autocomplete"
 77 | 
 78 | if dnf_install zsh-autocomplete 2>/dev/null && [[ -f "$ZSH_AUTOCOMPLETE_SYSTEM" ]]; then
 79 |     log_success "zsh-autocomplete installed via dnf"
 80 | else
 81 |     log_warn "zsh-autocomplete not in repos, cloning from GitHub..."
 82 |     ensure_dir "$HOME/.local/share/zsh/plugins"
 83 |     rm -rf "$ZSH_AUTOCOMPLETE_LOCAL" 2>/dev/null || true
 84 |     git clone --depth 1 https://github.com/marlonrichert/zsh-autocomplete.git "$ZSH_AUTOCOMPLETE_LOCAL"
 85 |     log_success "zsh-autocomplete cloned to $ZSH_AUTOCOMPLETE_LOCAL"
 86 | fi
 87 | 
 88 | # =============================================================================
 89 | # Restore Dotfiles
 90 | # =============================================================================
 91 | log_section "Restoring dotfiles..."
 92 | 
 93 | # .zshrc
 94 | if [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.zshrc" ]]; then
 95 |     cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.zshrc" ~/
 96 |     # Update zsh-autocomplete path if using local installation
 97 |     if [[ ! -f "$ZSH_AUTOCOMPLETE_SYSTEM" ]] && [[ -d "$ZSH_AUTOCOMPLETE_LOCAL" ]]; then
 98 |         sed -i "s|source /usr/share/zsh-autocomplete/zsh-autocomplete.plugin.zsh|source $ZSH_AUTOCOMPLETE_LOCAL/zsh-autocomplete.plugin.zsh|g" ~/.zshrc
 99 |         log_success ".zshrc copied and updated with local zsh-autocomplete path"
100 |     else
101 |         log_success ".zshrc copied"
102 |     fi
103 | fi
104 | 
105 | # .bashrc
106 | if [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.bashrc" ]]; then
107 |     cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.bashrc" ~/
108 |     log_success ".bashrc copied"
109 | fi
110 | 
111 | # .gitconfig
112 | if [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.gitconfig" ]]; then
113 |     if [[ -f ~/.gitconfig ]]; then
114 |         cp ~/.gitconfig ~/.gitconfig.backup
115 |         log_warn "Existing .gitconfig backed up"
116 |     fi
117 |     cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.gitconfig" ~/
118 |     log_success ".gitconfig copied"
119 | fi
120 | 
121 | # =============================================================================
122 | # Restore .config directories
123 | # =============================================================================
124 | log_section "Restoring .config directories..."
125 | ensure_dir ~/.config
126 | 
127 | # starship.toml
128 | if [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/starship/starship.toml" ]]; then
129 |     ensure_dir ~/.config/starship
130 |     cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/starship/starship.toml" ~/.config/starship/
131 |     log_success "starship.toml copied"
132 | elif [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/starship.toml" ]]; then
133 |     cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/starship.toml" ~/.config/
134 |     log_success "starship.toml copied"
135 | fi
136 | 
137 | # atuin config
138 | if [[ -d "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/atuin" ]]; then
139 |     copy_dir "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/atuin" ~/.config/atuin
140 | fi
141 | 
142 | # fastfetch config
143 | if [[ -d "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/fastfetch" ]]; then
144 |     copy_dir "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/fastfetch" ~/.config/fastfetch
145 | fi
146 | 
147 | # fastfetch custom logo
148 | if [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/images/jedi.png" ]]; then
149 |     ensure_dir ~/.config/fastfetch/assets
150 |     cp "$BACKUP_DIR/images/jedi.png" ~/.config/fastfetch/assets/
151 |     log_success "fastfetch custom logo (jedi.png) copied"
152 | fi
153 | 
154 | # fish config
155 | if [[ -d "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/fish" ]]; then
156 |     copy_dir "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/fish" ~/.config/fish
157 | fi
158 | 
159 | # kitty config
160 | if [[ -d "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/kitty" ]]; then
161 |     copy_dir "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/kitty" ~/.config/kitty
162 | fi
163 | 
164 | # tmux config
165 | if [[ -d "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/tmux" ]]; then
166 |     copy_dir "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/tmux" ~/.config/tmux
167 | elif [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.tmux.conf" ]]; then
168 |     ensure_dir ~/.config/tmux
169 |     cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.tmux.conf" ~/.config/tmux/tmux.conf
170 |     log_success "tmux.conf copied to ~/.config/tmux/"
171 | fi
172 | 
173 | # =============================================================================
174 | # Install Fonts
175 | # =============================================================================
176 | log_section "Installing fonts..."
177 | if [[ -d "$BACKUP_DIR/fonts" ]]; then
178 |     ensure_dir ~/.local/share/fonts
179 |     cp "$BACKUP_DIR/fonts/"*.ttf ~/.local/share/fonts/ 2>/dev/null || true
180 |     fc-cache -fv
181 |     log_success "Fonts installed and cache updated"
182 | else
183 |     log_warn "No fonts directory found in backup"
184 | fi
185 | 
186 | # =============================================================================
187 | # Change Default Shell to Zsh
188 | # =============================================================================
189 | log_section "Setting default shell to Zsh..."
190 | ZSH_PATH="$(which zsh)"
191 | if [[ "$SHELL" != "$ZSH_PATH" ]]; then
192 |     chsh -s "$ZSH_PATH"
193 |     log_success "Default shell changed to zsh (takes effect on next login)"
194 | else
195 |     log_success "Zsh is already the default shell"
196 | fi
197 | 
198 | log_section "Core setup complete!"
</content>
</file>
</files>

  31 | #: in an RTL script, the words "HELLO WORLD" display in kitty as

 213 | #: thickness of dark text on light backgrounds. Increasing the value
 214 | #: will make text appear thicker. The default value for this is 1.0 on
 215 | #: Linux and 1.7 on macOS. Valid values are 0.01 and above. The result
 216 | #: is scaled based on the luminance difference between the background
 217 | #: and the foreground. Dark text on light backgrounds receives the
 218 | #: full impact of the curve while light text on dark backgrounds is
 219 | #: affected very little.
 220 | 
 221 | #: The second number is an additional multiplicative contrast. It is
 222 | #: percentage ranging from 0 to 100. The default value is 0 on Linux
 223 | #: and 30 on macOS.
 224 | 
 225 | #: If you wish to achieve similar looking thickness in light and dark
 226 | #: themes, a good way to experiment is start by setting the value to
 227 | #: 1.0 0 and use a dark theme. Then adjust the second parameter until
 228 | #: it looks good. Then switch to a light theme and adjust the first
 229 | #: parameter until the perceived thickness matches the dark theme.
 230 | 
 231 | # text_fg_override_threshold 0
 232 | 
 233 | #: A setting to prevent low contrast between foreground and background
 234 | #: colors. Useful when working with applications that use colors that
 235 | #: do not contrast well with your preferred color scheme. The default
 236 | #: value is 0, which means no color overriding is performed. There are
 237 | #: two modes of operation:
 238 | 
 239 | #: A value with the suffix ratio represents the minimum accepted
 240 | #: contrast ratio between the foreground and background color.
 241 | #: Possible values range from 0.0 ratio to 21.0 ratio. For example, to
 242 | #: meet WCAG level AA
 243 | #: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_Content_Accessibility_Guidelines>
 244 | #: a value of 4.5 ratio can be provided. The algorithm is implemented
 245 | #: using HSLuv <https://www.hsluv.org/> which enables it to change the
 246 | #: perceived lightness of a color just as much as needed without
 247 | #: really changing its hue and saturation.
 248 | 
 249 | #: A value with the suffix % represents the minimum accepted
 250 | #: difference in luminance between the foreground and background
 251 | #: color, below which kitty will override the foreground color. It is
 252 | #: percentage ranging from 0 % to 100 %. If the difference in
 253 | #: luminance of the foreground and background is below this threshold,
 254 | #: the foreground color will be set to white if the background is dark
 255 | #: or black if the background is light.
 256 | 
 257 | #: WARNING: Some programs use characters (such as block characters)
 258 | #: for graphics display and may expect to be able to set the
 259 | #: foreground and background to the same color (or similar colors). If
 260 | #: you see unexpected stripes, dots, lines, incorrect color, no color
 261 | #: where you expect color, or any kind of graphic display problem try
 262 | #: setting text_fg_override_threshold to 0 to see if this is the cause
 263 | #: of the problem or consider using the ratio mode of operation
 264 | #: described above instead of the % mode of operation.
 265 | 
 266 | #: }}}
 267 | 
 268 | #: Text cursor customization {{{
 269 | 
 270 | # cursor #cccccc
 271 | 
 272 | #: Default text cursor color. If set to the special value none the
 273 | #: cursor will be rendered with a "reverse video" effect. Its color
 274 | #: will be the color of the text in the cell it is over and the text
 275 | #: will be rendered with the background color of the cell. Note that
 276 | #: if the program running in the terminal sets a cursor color, this
 277 | #: takes precedence. Also, the cursor colors are modified if the cell
 278 | #: background and foreground colors have very low contrast. Note that
 279 | #: some themes set this value, so if you want to override it, place
 280 | #: your value after the lines where the theme file is included.
 281 | 
 282 | # cursor_text_color #111111
 283 | 
 284 | #: The color of text under the cursor. If you want it rendered with
 285 | #: the background color of the cell underneath instead, use the
 286 | #: special keyword: `background`. Note that if cursor is set to none
 287 | #: then this option is ignored. Note that some themes set this value,
 288 | #: so if you want to override it, place your value after the lines
 289 | #: where the theme file is included.
 290 | 
 291 | # cursor_shape block
 292 | 
 293 | #: The cursor shape can be one of block, beam, underline. Note that
 294 | #: when reloading the config this will be changed only if the cursor
 295 | #: shape has not been set by the program running in the terminal. This
 296 | #: sets the default cursor shape, applications running in the terminal
 297 | #: can override it. In particular, shell integration
 298 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/shell-integration/> in kitty sets
 299 | #: the cursor shape to beam at shell prompts. You can avoid this by
 300 | #: setting shell_integration to no-cursor.
 301 | 
 302 | # cursor_shape_unfocused hollow
 303 | 
 304 | #: Defines the text cursor shape when the OS window is not focused.
 305 | #: The unfocused cursor shape can be one of block, beam, underline,
 306 | #: hollow and unchanged (leave the cursor shape as it is).
 307 | 
 308 | # cursor_beam_thickness 1.5
 309 | 
 310 | #: The thickness of the beam cursor (in pts).
 311 | 
 312 | # cursor_underline_thickness 2.0
 313 | 
 314 | #: The thickness of the underline cursor (in pts).
 315 | 
 316 | # cursor_blink_interval -1
 317 | 
 318 | #: The interval to blink the cursor (in seconds). Set to zero to
 319 | #: disable blinking. Negative values mean use system default. Note
 320 | #: that the minimum interval will be limited to repaint_delay. You can
 321 | #: also animate the cursor blink by specifying an easing function. For
 322 | #: example, setting this to option to 0.5 ease-in-out will cause the
 323 | #: cursor blink to be animated over a second, in the first half of the
 324 | #: second it will go from opaque to transparent and then back again
 325 | #: over the next half. You can specify different easing functions for
 326 | #: the two halves, for example: -1 linear ease-out. kitty supports all
 327 | #: the CSS easing functions <https://developer.mozilla.org/en-
 328 | #: US/docs/Web/CSS/easing-function>. Note that turning on animations
 329 | #: uses extra power as it means the screen is redrawn multiple times
 330 | #: per blink interval. See also, cursor_stop_blinking_after. This
 331 | #: setting also controls blinking text, which blinks in exact rhythm
 332 | #: with the cursor.
 333 | 
 334 | # cursor_stop_blinking_after 15.0
 335 | 
 336 | #: Stop blinking cursor after the specified number of seconds of
 337 | #: keyboard inactivity. Set to zero to never stop blinking. This
 338 | #: setting also controls blinking text, which blinks in exact rhythm
 339 | #: with the cursor.
 340 | 
 341 | cursor_trail 100
 342 | 
 343 | #: Set this to a value larger than zero to enable a "cursor trail"
 344 | #: animation. This is an animation that shows a "trail" following the
 345 | #: movement of the text cursor. It makes it easy to follow large
 346 | #: cursor jumps and makes for a cool visual effect of the cursor
 347 | #: zooming around the screen. The actual value of this option controls
 348 | #: when the animation is triggered. It is a number of milliseconds.
 349 | #: The trail animation only follows cursors that have stayed in their
 350 | #: position for longer than the specified number of milliseconds. This
 351 | #: prevents trails from appearing for cursors that rapidly change
 352 | #: their positions during UI updates in complex applications. See
 353 | #: cursor_trail_decay to control the animation speed and
 354 | #: cursor_trail_start_threshold to control when a cursor trail is
 355 | #: started.
 356 | 
 357 | cursor_trail_decay 0.1 0.4
 358 | 
 359 | #: Controls the decay times for the cursor trail effect when the
 360 | #: cursor_trail is enabled. This option accepts two positive float
 361 | #: values specifying the fastest and slowest decay times in seconds.
 362 | #: The first value corresponds to the fastest decay time (minimum),
 363 | #: and the second value corresponds to the slowest decay time
 364 | #: (maximum). The second value must be equal to or greater than the
 365 | #: first value. Smaller values result in a faster decay of the cursor
 366 | #: trail. Adjust these values to control how quickly the cursor trail
 367 | #: fades away.
 368 | 
 369 | cursor_trail_start_threshold 2
 370 | 
 371 | #: Set the distance threshold for starting the cursor trail. This
 372 | #: option accepts a positive integer value that represents the minimum
 373 | #: number of cells the cursor must move before the trail is started.
 374 | #: When the cursor moves less than this threshold, the trail is
 375 | #: skipped, reducing unnecessary cursor trail animation.
 376 | 
 377 | # cursor_trail_color none
 378 | 
 379 | #: Set the color of the cursor trail when cursor_trail is enabled. If
 380 | #: set to 'none' (the default), the cursor trail will use the cursor's
 381 | #: background color. Otherwise, specify a color value (e.g., #ff0000
 382 | #: for red, or a named color like 'red'). This allows you to customize
 383 | #: the appearance of the cursor trail independently of the cursor
 384 | #: color.
 385 | 
 386 | #: }}}
 387 | 
 388 | #: Scrollback {{{
 389 | 
 390 | # scrollback_lines 2000
 391 | 
 392 | #: Number of lines of history to keep in memory for scrolling back.
 393 | #: Memory is allocated on demand. Negative numbers are (effectively)
 394 | #: infinite scrollback. Note that using very large scrollback is not
 395 | #: recommended as it can slow down performance of the terminal and
 396 | #: also use large amounts of RAM. Instead, consider using
 397 | #: scrollback_pager_history_size. Note that on config reload if this
 398 | #: is changed it will only affect newly created windows, not existing
 399 | #: ones.
 400 | 
 401 | # scrollbar scrolled
 402 | 
 403 | #: Control when the scrollbar is displayed.
 404 | 
 405 | #: scrolled
 406 | #:     means when the scrolling backwards has started.
 407 | #: hovered
 408 | #:     means when the mouse is hovering on the right edge of the window.
 409 | #: scrolled-and-hovered
 410 | #:     means when the mouse is over the scrollbar region *and* scrolling backwards has started.
 411 | #: always
 412 | #:     means whenever any scrollback is present
 413 | #: never
 414 | #:     means disable the scrollbar.
 415 | 
 416 | # scrollbar_interactive yes
 417 | 
 418 | #: If disabled, the scrollbar will not be controllable via th emouse
 419 | #: and all mouse events will pass through the scrollbar.
 420 | 
 421 | # scrollbar_jump_on_click yes
 422 | 
 423 | #: When enabled clicking in the scrollbar track will cause the scroll
 424 | #: position to jump to the clicked location, otherwise the scroll
 425 | #: position will only move towards the position by a single screenful,
 426 | #: which is how traditional scrollbars behave.
 427 | 
 428 | # scrollbar_width 0.5
 429 | 
 430 | #: The width of the scroll bar in units of cell width.
 431 | 
 432 | # scrollbar_hover_width 1
 433 | 
 434 | #: The width of the scroll bar when the mouse is hovering over it, in
 435 | #: units of cell width.
 436 | 
 437 | # scrollbar_handle_opacity 0.5
 438 | 
 439 | #: The opacity of the scrollbar handle, 0 being fully transparent and
 440 | #: 1 being full opaque.
 441 | 
 442 | # scrollbar_radius 0.3
 443 | 
 444 | #: The radius (curvature) of the scrollbar handle in units of cell
 445 | #: width. Should be less than scrollbar_width.
 446 | 
 447 | # scrollbar_gap 0.1
 448 | 
 449 | #: The gap between the scrollbar and the window edge in units of cell
 450 | #: width.
 451 | 
 452 | # scrollbar_min_handle_height 1
 453 | 
 454 | #: The minimum height of the scrollbar handle in units of cell height.
 455 | #: Prevents the handle from becoming too small when there is a lot of
 456 | #: scrollback.
 457 | 
 458 | # scrollbar_hitbox_expansion 0.25
 459 | 
 460 | #: The extra area around the handle to allow easier grabbing of the
 461 | #: scollbar in units of cell width.
 462 | 
 463 | # scrollbar_track_opacity 0
 464 | 
 465 | #: The opacity of the scrollbar track, 0 being fully transparent and 1
 466 | #: being full opaque.
 467 | 
 468 | # scrollbar_track_hover_opacity 0.1
 469 | 
 470 | #: The opacity of the scrollbar track when the mouse is over the
 471 | #: scrollbar, 0 being fully transparent and 1 being full opaque.
 472 | 
 473 | # scrollbar_handle_color foreground
 474 | 
 475 | #: The color of the scrollbar handle. A value of foreground means to
 476 | #: use the current foreground text color, a value of
 477 | #: selection_background means to use the current selection background
 478 | #: color. Also, you can use an arbitrary color, such as #12af59 or
 479 | #: red.
 480 | 
 481 | # scrollbar_track_color foreground
 482 | 
 483 | #: The color of the scrollbar track. A value of foreground means to
 484 | #: use the current foreground text color, a value of
 485 | #: selection_background means to use the current selection background
 486 | #: color. Also, you can use an arbitrary color, such as #12af59 or
 487 | #: red.
 488 | 
 489 | # scrollback_pager less --chop-long-lines --RAW-CONTROL-CHARS +INPUT_LINE_NUMBER
 490 | 
 491 | #: Program with which to view scrollback in a new window. The
 492 | #: scrollback buffer is passed as STDIN to this program. If you change
 493 | #: it, make sure the program you use can handle ANSI escape sequences
 494 | #: for colors and text formatting. INPUT_LINE_NUMBER in the command
 495 | #: line above will be replaced by an integer representing which line
 496 | #: should be at the top of the screen. Similarly CURSOR_LINE and
 497 | #: CURSOR_COLUMN will be replaced by the current cursor position or
 498 | #: set to 0 if there is no cursor, for example, when showing the last
 499 | #: command output.
 500 | 
 501 | #: If you would rather use neovim to view the scrollback, use
 502 | #: something like this::
 503 | 
 504 | #:     scrollback_pager nvim --cmd 'set eventignore=FileType' +'nnoremap q ZQ' +'call nvim_open_term(0, {})' +'set nomodified nolist' +'$' -
 505 | 
 506 | #: The above works for neovim 0.12 and newer. There is also a
 507 | #: dedicated plugin kitty-scrollback.nvim
 508 | #: <https://github.com/mikesmithgh/kitty-scrollback.nvim> you can use
 509 | #: with more features that works with older neovim as well.
 510 | 
 511 | # scrollback_pager_history_size 0
 512 | 
 513 | #: Separate scrollback history size (in MB), used only for browsing
 514 | #: the scrollback buffer with pager. This separate buffer is not
 515 | #: available for interactive scrolling but will be piped to the pager
 516 | #: program when viewing scrollback buffer in a separate window. The
 517 | #: current implementation stores the data in UTF-8, so approximately
 518 | #: 10000 lines per megabyte at 100 chars per line, for pure ASCII,
 519 | #: unformatted text. A value of zero or less disables this feature.
 520 | #: The maximum allowed size is 4GB. Note that on config reload if this
 521 | #: is changed it will only affect newly created windows, not existing
 522 | #: ones.
 523 | 
 524 | # scrollback_fill_enlarged_window no
 525 | 
 526 | #: Fill new space with lines from the scrollback buffer after
 527 | #: enlarging a window.
 528 | 
 529 | # wheel_scroll_multiplier 5.0
 530 | 
 531 | #: Multiplier for the number of lines scrolled by the mouse wheel.
 532 | #: Note that this is only used for low precision scrolling devices,
 533 | #: not for high precision scrolling devices on platforms such as macOS
 534 | #: and Wayland. Use negative numbers to change scroll direction. See
 535 | #: also wheel_scroll_min_lines.
 536 | 
 537 | # wheel_scroll_min_lines 1
 538 | 
 539 | #: The minimum number of lines scrolled by the mouse wheel. The scroll
 540 | #: multiplier wheel_scroll_multiplier only takes effect after it
 541 | #: reaches this number. Note that this is only used for low precision
 542 | #: scrolling devices like wheel mice that scroll by very small amounts
 543 | #: when using the wheel. With a negative number, the minimum number of
 544 | #: lines will always be added.
 545 | 
 546 | # touch_scroll_multiplier 1.0
 547 | 
 548 | #: Multiplier for the number of lines scrolled by a touchpad. Note
 549 | #: that this is only used for high precision scrolling devices on
 550 | #: platforms such as macOS and Wayland. Use negative numbers to change
 551 | #: scroll direction.
 552 | 
 553 | #: }}}
 554 | 
 555 | #: Mouse {{{
 556 | 
 557 | # mouse_hide_wait 3.0
 558 | 
 559 | #: Hide mouse cursor after the specified number of seconds of the
 560 | #: mouse not being used. Set to zero to disable mouse cursor hiding.
 561 | #: Set to a negative value to hide the mouse cursor immediately when
 562 | #: typing text. Disabled by default on macOS as getting it to work
 563 | #: robustly with the ever-changing sea of bugs that is Cocoa is too
 564 | #: much effort.
 565 | 
 566 | #: By default, once the cursor is hidden, it is immediately unhidden
 567 | #: on any further mouse events.
 568 | 
 569 | #: Two formats are supported:
 570 | #:  - <hide-wait>
 571 | #:  - <hide-wait> <unhide-wait> <unhide-threshold> <scroll-unhide>
 572 | 
 573 | #: To change the unhide behavior, the optional parameters <unhide-
 574 | #: wait>, <unhide-threshold>, and <scroll-unhide> may be set.
 575 | 
 576 | #: <unhide-wait>
 577 | #:     Waits for the specified number of seconds after mouse events before unhiding the
 578 | #:     mouse cursor. Set to zero to unhide mouse cursor immediately on mouse activity.
 579 | #:     This is useful to prevent the mouse cursor from unhiding on accidental swipes on
 580 | #:     the trackpad.
 581 | 
 582 | #: <unhide-threshold>
 583 | #:     Sets the threshold of mouse activity required to unhide the mouse cursor, when
 584 | #:     the <unhide-wait> option is non-zero. When <unhide-wait> is zero, this has no
 585 | #:     effect.
 586 | 
 587 | #:     For example, if <unhide-threshold> is 40 and <unhide-wait> is 2.5, when kitty
 588 | #:     detects a mouse event, it records the number of mouse events in the next 2.5
 589 | #:     seconds, and checks if that exceeds 40 * 2.5 = 100. If it does, then the mouse
 590 | #:     cursor is unhidden, otherwise nothing happens.
 591 | 
 592 | #: <scroll-unhide>
 593 | #:     Controls what mouse events may unhide the mouse cursor. If enabled, both scroll
 594 | #:     and movement events may unhide the cursor. If disabled, only mouse movements can
 595 | #:     unhide the cursor.
 596 | 
 597 | #: Examples of valid values:
 598 | #:  - 0.0
 599 | #:  - 1.0
 600 | #:  - -1.0
 601 | #:  - 0.1 3.0 40 yes
 602 | 
 603 | # url_color #0087bd
 604 | # url_style curly
 605 | 
 606 | #: The color and style for highlighting URLs on mouse-over. url_style
 607 | #: can be one of: none, straight, double, curly, dotted, dashed.
 608 | 
 609 | # open_url_with default
 610 | 
 611 | #: The program to open clicked URLs. The special value default will
 612 | #: first look for any URL handlers defined via the open_actions
 613 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/open_actions/> facility and if non
 614 | #: are found, it will use the Operating System's default URL handler
 615 | #: (open on macOS and xdg-open on Linux).
 616 | 
 617 | # url_prefixes file ftp ftps gemini git gopher http https irc ircs kitty mailto news sftp ssh
 618 | 
 619 | #: The set of URL prefixes to look for when detecting a URL under the
 620 | #: mouse cursor.
 621 | 
 622 | # detect_urls yes
 623 | 
 624 | #: Detect URLs under the mouse. Detected URLs are highlighted with an
 625 | #: underline and the mouse cursor becomes a hand over them. Even if
 626 | #: this option is disabled, URLs are still clickable. See also the
 627 | #: underline_hyperlinks option to control how hyperlinks (as opposed
 628 | #: to plain text URLs) are displayed.
 629 | 
 630 | # url_excluded_characters
 631 | 
 632 | #: Additional characters to be disallowed from URLs, when detecting
 633 | #: URLs under the mouse cursor. By default, all characters that are
 634 | #: legal in URLs are allowed. Additionally, newlines are allowed (but
 635 | #: stripped). This is to accommodate programs such as mutt that add
 636 | #: hard line breaks even for continued lines. \n can be added to this
 637 | #: option to disable this behavior. Special characters can be
 638 | #: specified using backslash escapes, to specify a backslash use a
 639 | #: double backslash.
 640 | 
 641 | # show_hyperlink_targets no
 642 | 
 643 | #: When the mouse hovers over a terminal hyperlink, show the actual
 644 | #: URL that will be activated when the hyperlink is clicked.
 645 | 
 646 | # underline_hyperlinks hover
 647 | 
 648 | #: Control how hyperlinks are underlined. They can either be
 649 | #: underlined on mouse hover, always (i.e. permanently underlined) or
 650 | #: never which means that kitty will not apply any underline styling
 651 | #: to hyperlinks. Note that the value of always only applies to real
 652 | #: (OSC 8) hyperlinks not text that is detected to be a URL on mouse
 653 | #: hover. Uses the url_style and url_color settings for the underline
 654 | #: style. Note that reloading the config and changing this value
 655 | #: to/from always will only affect text subsequently received by
 656 | #: kitty.
 657 | 
 658 | # copy_on_select no
 659 | 
 660 | #: Copy to clipboard or a private buffer on select. With this set to
 661 | #: clipboard, selecting text with the mouse will cause the text to be
 662 | #: copied to clipboard. Useful on platforms such as macOS that do not
 663 | #: have the concept of primary selection. You can instead specify a
 664 | #: name such as a1 to copy to a private kitty buffer. Map a shortcut
 665 | #: with the paste_from_buffer action to paste from this private
 666 | #: buffer. For example::
 667 | 
 668 | #:     copy_on_select a1
 669 | #:     map shift+cmd+v paste_from_buffer a1
 670 | 
 671 | #: Note that copying to the clipboard is a security risk, as all
 672 | #: programs, including websites open in your browser can read the
 673 | #: contents of the system clipboard.
 674 | 
 675 | # clear_selection_on_clipboard_loss no
 676 | 
 677 | #: When the contents of the clipboard no longer reflect the current
 678 | #: selection, clear it. This is primarily useful on platforms such as
 679 | #: Linux where selecting text automatically copies it to a special
 680 | #: "primary selection" clipboard or if you have copy_on_select set to
 681 | #: clipboard.
 682 | 
 683 | #: Note that on macOS the system does not provide notifications when
 684 | #: the clipboard owner is changed, so there, copying to clipboard in a
 685 | #: non-kitty application will not clear selections even if
 686 | #: copy_on_select is enabled.
 687 | 
 688 | # paste_actions quote-urls-at-prompt,confirm
 689 | 
 690 | #: A comma separated list of actions to take when pasting text into
 691 | #: the terminal. The supported paste actions are:
 692 | 
 693 | #: quote-urls-at-prompt:
 694 | #:     If the text being pasted is a URL and the cursor is at a shell prompt,
 695 | #:     automatically quote the URL (needs shell_integration).
 696 | #: replace-dangerous-control-codes
 697 | #:     Replace dangerous control codes from pasted text, without confirmation.
 698 | #: replace-newline
 699 | #:     Replace the newline character from pasted text, without confirmation.
 700 | #: confirm:
 701 | #:     Confirm the paste if the text to be pasted contains any terminal control codes
 702 | #:     as this can be dangerous, leading to code execution if the shell/program running
 703 | #:     in the terminal does not properly handle these.
 704 | #: confirm-if-large
 705 | #:     Confirm the paste if it is very large (larger than 16KB) as pasting
 706 | #:     large amounts of text into shells can be very slow.
 707 | #: filter:
 708 | #:     Run the filter_paste() function from the file paste-actions.py in
 709 | #:     the kitty config directory on the pasted text. The text returned by the
 710 | #:     function will be actually pasted.
 711 | #: no-op:
 712 | #:     Has no effect.
 713 | 
 714 | # strip_trailing_spaces never
 715 | 
 716 | #: Remove spaces at the end of lines when copying to clipboard. A
 717 | #: value of smart will do it when using normal selections, but not
 718 | #: rectangle selections. A value of always will always do it.
 719 | 
 720 | # select_by_word_characters @-./_~?&=%+#
 721 | 
 722 | #: Characters considered part of a word when double clicking. In
 723 | #: addition to these characters any character that is marked as an
 724 | #: alphanumeric character in the Unicode database will be matched.
 725 | 
 726 | # select_by_word_characters_forward
 727 | 
 728 | #: Characters considered part of a word when extending the selection
 729 | #: forward on double clicking. In addition to these characters any
 730 | #: character that is marked as an alphanumeric character in the
 731 | #: Unicode database will be matched.
 732 | 
 733 | #: If empty (default) select_by_word_characters will be used for both
 734 | #: directions.
 735 | 
 736 | # click_interval -1.0
 737 | 
 738 | #: The interval between successive clicks to detect double/triple
 739 | #: clicks (in seconds). Negative numbers will use the system default
 740 | #: instead, if available, or fallback to 0.5.
 741 | 
 742 | # focus_follows_mouse no
 743 | 
 744 | #: Set the active window to the window under the mouse when moving the
 745 | #: mouse around. On macOS, this will also cause the OS Window under
 746 | #: the mouse to be focused automatically when the mouse enters it.
 747 | 
 748 | # pointer_shape_when_grabbed arrow
 749 | 
 750 | #: The shape of the mouse pointer when the program running in the
 751 | #: terminal grabs the mouse.
 752 | 
 753 | # default_pointer_shape beam
 754 | 
 755 | #: The default shape of the mouse pointer.
 756 | 
 757 | # pointer_shape_when_dragging beam crosshair
 758 | 
 759 | #: The default shape of the mouse pointer when dragging across text.
 760 | #: The optional second value sets the shape when dragging in
 761 | #: rectangular selection mode.
 762 | 
 763 | #: Mouse actions {{{
 764 | 
 765 | #: Mouse buttons can be mapped to perform arbitrary actions. The
 766 | #: syntax is:
 767 | 
 768 | #: .. code-block:: none
 769 | 
 770 | #:     mouse_map button-name event-type modes action
 771 | 
 772 | #: Where button-name is one of left, middle, right, b1 ... b8 with
 773 | #: added keyboard modifiers. For example: ctrl+shift+left refers to
 774 | #: holding the Ctrl+Shift keys while clicking with the left mouse
 775 | #: button. The value b1 ... b8 can be used to refer to up to eight
 776 | #: buttons on a mouse.
 777 | 
 778 | #: event-type is one of press, release, doublepress, triplepress,
 779 | #: click, doubleclick. modes indicates whether the action is performed
 780 | #: when the mouse is grabbed by the program running in the terminal,
 781 | #: or not. The values are grabbed or ungrabbed or a comma separated
 782 | #: combination of them. grabbed refers to when the program running in
 783 | #: the terminal has requested mouse events. Note that the click and
 784 | #: double click events have a delay of click_interval to disambiguate
 785 | #: from double and triple presses.
 786 | 
 787 | #: You can run kitty with the kitty --debug-input command line option
 788 | #: to see mouse events. See the builtin actions below to get a sense
 789 | #: of what is possible.
 790 | 
 791 | #: If you want to unmap a button, map it to nothing. For example, to
 792 | #: disable opening of URLs with a plain click::
 793 | 
 794 | #:     mouse_map left click ungrabbed
 795 | 
 796 | #: See all the mappable actions including mouse actions here
 797 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/actions/>.
 798 | 
 799 | #: .. note::
 800 | #:     Once a selection is started, releasing the button that started it will
 801 | #:     automatically end it and no release event will be dispatched.
 802 | 
 803 | # clear_all_mouse_actions no
 804 | 
 805 | #: Remove all mouse action definitions up to this point. Useful, for
 806 | #: instance, to remove the default mouse actions.
 807 | 
 808 | #: Click the link under the mouse or move the cursor
 809 | 
 810 | # mouse_map left click ungrabbed mouse_handle_click selection link prompt
 811 | 
 812 | #::  First check for a selection and if one exists do nothing. Then
 813 | #::  check for a link under the mouse cursor and if one exists, click
 814 | #::  it. Finally check if the click happened at the current shell
 815 | #::  prompt and if so, move the cursor to the click location. Note
 816 | #::  that this requires shell integration
 817 | #::  <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/shell-integration/> to work.
 818 | 
 819 | #: Click the link under the mouse or move the cursor even when grabbed
 820 | 
 821 | # mouse_map shift+left click grabbed,ungrabbed mouse_handle_click selection link prompt
 822 | 
 823 | #::  Same as above, except that the action is performed even when the
 824 | #::  mouse is grabbed by the program running in the terminal.
 825 | 
 826 | #: Click the link under the mouse cursor
 827 | 
 828 | # mouse_map ctrl+shift+left release grabbed,ungrabbed mouse_handle_click link
 829 | 
 830 | #::  Variant with Ctrl+Shift is present because the simple click based
 831 | #::  version has an unavoidable delay of click_interval, to
 832 | #::  disambiguate clicks from double clicks.
 833 | 
 834 | #: Discard press event for link click
 835 | 
 836 | # mouse_map ctrl+shift+left press grabbed discard_event
 837 | 
 838 | #::  Prevent this press event from being sent to the program that has
 839 | #::  grabbed the mouse, as the corresponding release event is used to
 840 | #::  open a URL.
 841 | 
 842 | #: Paste from the primary selection
 843 | 
 844 | # mouse_map middle release ungrabbed paste_from_selection
 845 | 
 846 | #: Start selecting text
 847 | 
 848 | # mouse_map left press ungrabbed mouse_selection normal
 849 | 
 850 | #: Start selecting text in a rectangle
 851 | 
 852 | # mouse_map ctrl+alt+left press ungrabbed mouse_selection rectangle
 853 | 
 854 | #: Select a word
 855 | 
 856 | # mouse_map left doublepress ungrabbed mouse_selection word
 857 | 
 858 | #: Select a line
 859 | 
 860 | # mouse_map left triplepress ungrabbed mouse_selection line
 861 | 
 862 | #: Select line from point
 863 | 
 864 | # mouse_map ctrl+alt+left triplepress ungrabbed mouse_selection line_from_point
 865 | 
 866 | #::  Select from the clicked point to the end of the line. If you
 867 | #::  would like to select the word at the point and then extend to the
 868 | #::  rest of the line, change `line_from_point` to
 869 | #::  `word_and_line_from_point`.
 870 | 
 871 | #: Extend the current selection
 872 | 
 873 | # mouse_map right press ungrabbed mouse_selection extend
 874 | 
 875 | #::  If you want only the end of the selection to be moved instead of
 876 | #::  the nearest boundary, use move-end instead of extend.
 877 | 
 878 | #: Paste from the primary selection even when grabbed
 879 | 
 880 | # mouse_map shift+middle release ungrabbed,grabbed paste_selection
 881 | # mouse_map shift+middle press grabbed discard_event
 882 | 
 883 | #: Start selecting text even when grabbed
 884 | 
 885 | # mouse_map shift+left press ungrabbed,grabbed mouse_selection normal
 886 | 
 887 | #: Start selecting text in a rectangle even when grabbed
 888 | 
 889 | # mouse_map ctrl+shift+alt+left press ungrabbed,grabbed mouse_selection rectangle
 890 | 
 891 | #: Select a word even when grabbed
 892 | 
 893 | # mouse_map shift+left doublepress ungrabbed,grabbed mouse_selection word
 894 | 
 895 | #: Select a line even when grabbed
 896 | 
 897 | # mouse_map shift+left triplepress ungrabbed,grabbed mouse_selection line
 898 | 
 899 | #: Select line from point even when grabbed
 900 | 
 901 | # mouse_map ctrl+shift+alt+left triplepress ungrabbed,grabbed mouse_selection line_from_point
 902 | 
 903 | #::  Select from the clicked point to the end of the line even when
 904 | #::  grabbed. If you would like to select the word at the point and
 905 | #::  then extend to the rest of the line, change `line_from_point` to
 906 | #::  `word_and_line_from_point`.
 907 | 
 908 | #: Extend the current selection even when grabbed
 909 | 
 910 | # mouse_map shift+right press ungrabbed,grabbed mouse_selection extend
 911 | 
 912 | #: Show clicked command output in pager
 913 | 
 914 | # mouse_map ctrl+shift+right press ungrabbed mouse_show_command_output
 915 | 
 916 | #::  Requires shell integration
 917 | #::  <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/shell-integration/> to work.
 918 | 
 919 | #: }}}
 920 | 
 921 | #: }}}
 922 | 
 923 | #: Performance tuning {{{
 924 | 
 925 | # repaint_delay 10
 926 | 
 927 | #: Delay between screen updates (in milliseconds). Decreasing it,
 928 | #: increases frames-per-second (FPS) at the cost of more CPU usage.
 929 | #: The default value yields ~100 FPS which is more than sufficient for
 930 | #: most uses. Note that to actually achieve 100 FPS, you have to
 931 | #: either set sync_to_monitor to no or use a monitor with a high
 932 | #: refresh rate. Also, to minimize latency when there is pending input
 933 | #: to be processed, this option is ignored.
 934 | 
 935 | # input_delay 3
 936 | 
 937 | #: Delay before input from the program running in the terminal is
 938 | #: processed (in milliseconds). Note that decreasing it will increase
 939 | #: responsiveness, but also increase CPU usage and might cause flicker
 940 | #: in full screen programs that redraw the entire screen on each loop,
 941 | #: because kitty is so fast that partial screen updates will be drawn.
 942 | #: This setting is ignored when the input buffer is almost full.
 943 | 
 944 | # sync_to_monitor yes
 945 | 
 946 | #: Sync screen updates to the refresh rate of the monitor. This
 947 | #: prevents screen tearing
 948 | #: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screen_tearing> when scrolling.
 949 | #: However, it limits the rendering speed to the refresh rate of your
 950 | #: monitor. With a very high speed mouse/high keyboard repeat rate,
 951 | #: you may notice some slight input latency. If so, set this to no.
 952 | 
 953 | #: }}}
 954 | 
 955 | #: Terminal bell {{{
 956 | 
 957 | # enable_audio_bell yes
 958 | 
 959 | #: The audio bell. Useful to disable it in environments that require
 960 | #: silence.
 961 | 
 962 | # visual_bell_duration 0.0
 963 | 
 964 | #: The visual bell duration (in seconds). Flash the screen when a bell
 965 | #: occurs for the specified number of seconds. Set to zero to disable.
 966 | #: The flash is animated, fading in and out over the specified
 967 | #: duration. The easing function used for the fading can be
 968 | #: controlled. For example, 2.0 linear will casuse the flash to fade
 969 | #: in and out linearly. The default if unspecified is to use ease-in-
 970 | #: out which fades slowly at the start, middle and end. You can
 971 | #: specify different easing functions for the fade-in and fade-out
 972 | #: parts, like this: 2.0 ease-in linear. kitty supports all the CSS
 973 | #: easing functions <https://developer.mozilla.org/en-
 974 | #: US/docs/Web/CSS/easing-function>.
 975 | 
 976 | # visual_bell_color none
 977 | 
 978 | #: The color used by visual bell. Set to none will fall back to
 979 | #: selection background color. If you feel that the visual bell is too
 980 | #: bright, you can set it to a darker color.
 981 | 
 982 | # window_alert_on_bell yes
 983 | 
 984 | #: Request window attention on bell. Makes the dock icon bounce on
 985 | #: macOS or the taskbar flash on Linux.
 986 | 
 987 | # bell_on_tab "🔔 "
 988 | 
 989 | #: Some text or a Unicode symbol to show on the tab if a window in the
 990 | #: tab that does not have focus has a bell. If you want to use leading
 991 | #: or trailing spaces, surround the text with quotes. See
 992 | #: tab_title_template for how this is rendered.
 993 | 
 994 | #: For backwards compatibility, values of yes, y and true are
 995 | #: converted to the default bell symbol and no, n, false and none are
 996 | #: converted to the empty string.
 997 | 
 998 | # command_on_bell none
 999 | 
1000 | #: Program to run when a bell occurs. The environment variable
1001 | #: KITTY_CHILD_CMDLINE can be used to get the program running in the
1002 | #: window in which the bell occurred.
1003 | 
1004 | # bell_path none
1005 | 
1006 | #: Path to a sound file to play as the bell sound. If set to none, the
1007 | #: system default bell sound is used. Must be in a format supported by
1008 | #: the operating systems sound API, such as WAV or OGA on Linux
1009 | #: (libcanberra) or AIFF, MP3 or WAV on macOS (NSSound). Relative
1010 | #: paths are resolved with respect to the kitty config directory.
1011 | 
1012 | # linux_bell_theme __custom
1013 | 
1014 | #: The XDG Sound Theme kitty will use to play the bell sound. On
1015 | #: Wayland, when the compositor supports it, it is asked to play the
1016 | #: system default bell sound, and this setting has no effect. Note
1017 | #: that Hyprland claims to support this protocol, but does not
1018 | #: actually play a sound
1019 | #: <https://github.com/hyprwm/Hyprland/issues/10488>. This setting
1020 | #: defaults to the custom theme name specified in the XDG Sound theme
1021 | #: specification <https://specifications.freedesktop.org/sound-theme-
1022 | #: spec/latest/sound_lookup.html>, falling back to the default
1023 | #: freedesktop theme if it does not exist. To change your sound theme
1024 | #: desktop wide, create
1025 | #: :file:~/.local/share/sounds/__custom/index.theme` with the
1026 | #: contents:
1027 | 
1028 | #:     [Sound Theme]
1029 | 
1030 | #:     Inherits=name-of-the-sound-theme-you-want-to-use
1031 | 
1032 | #: Replace name-of-the-sound-theme-you-want-to-use with the actual
1033 | #: theme name. Now all compliant applications should use sounds from
1034 | #: this theme.
1035 | 
1036 | #: }}}
1037 | 
1038 | #: Window layout {{{
1039 | 
1040 | remember_window_size  no
1041 | initial_window_width  120c
1042 | initial_window_height 25c
1043 | 
1044 | #: If enabled, the OS Window size will be remembered so that new
1045 | #: instances of kitty will have the same size as the previous
1046 | #: instance. If disabled, the OS Window will initially have size
1047 | #: configured by initial_window_width/height, in pixels. You can use a
1048 | #: suffix of "c" on the width/height values to have them interpreted
1049 | #: as number of cells instead of pixels.
1050 | 
1051 | remember_window_position no
1052 | 
1053 | #: If enabled, the OS Window position will be remembered so that new
1054 | #: instances of kitty will have the same position as the previous
1055 | #: instance. If disabled, the OS Window will be placed by the window
1056 | #: manager. Note that remembering of position only works if the
1057 | #: underlying desktop environment/window manager supports it. It never
1058 | #: works on Wayland. See also kitty --position to specify the position
1059 | #: when launching kitty.
1060 | 
1061 | # enabled_layouts *
1062 | 
1063 | #: The enabled window layouts. A comma separated list of layout names.
1064 | #: The special value all means all layouts. The first listed layout
1065 | #: will be used as the startup layout. Default configuration is all
1066 | #: layouts in alphabetical order. For a list of available layouts, see
1067 | #: the layouts <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/overview/#layouts>.
1068 | 
1069 | # window_resize_step_cells 2
1070 | # window_resize_step_lines 2
1071 | 
1072 | #: The step size (in units of cell width/cell height) to use when
1073 | #: resizing kitty windows in a layout with the shortcut
1074 | #: start_resizing_window. The cells value is used for horizontal
1075 | #: resizing, and the lines value is used for vertical resizing.
1076 | 
1077 | # window_border_width 0
1078 | 
1079 | #: The width of window borders. Can be either in pixels (px) or pts
1080 | #: (pt). Values in pts will be rounded to the nearest number of pixels
1081 | #: based on screen resolution. If not specified, the unit is assumed
1082 | #: to be pts. Note that borders are displayed only when more than one
1083 | #: window is visible. They are meant to separate multiple windows.
1084 | 
1085 | # draw_minimal_borders yes
1086 | 
1087 | #: Draw only the minimum borders needed. This means that only the
1088 | #: borders that separate the window from a neighbor are drawn. Note
1089 | #: that setting a non-zero window_margin_width overrides this and
1090 | #: causes all borders to be drawn.
1091 | 
1092 | # window_margin_width 0
1093 | 
1094 | #: The window margin (in pts) (blank area outside the border). A
1095 | #: single value sets all four sides. Two values set the vertical and
1096 | #: horizontal sides. Three values set top, horizontal and bottom. Four
1097 | #: values set top, right, bottom and left.
1098 | 
1099 | # single_window_margin_width -1
1100 | 
1101 | #: The window margin to use when only a single window is visible (in
1102 | #: pts). Negative values will cause the value of window_margin_width
1103 | #: to be used instead. A single value sets all four sides. Two values
1104 | #: set the vertical and horizontal sides. Three values set top,
1105 | #: horizontal and bottom. Four values set top, right, bottom and left.
1106 | 
1107 | # window_padding_width 0
1108 | 
1109 | #: The window padding (in pts) (blank area between the text and the
1110 | #: window border). A single value sets all four sides. Two values set
1111 | #: the vertical and horizontal sides. Three values set top, horizontal
1112 | #: and bottom. Four values set top, right, bottom and left.
1113 | 
1114 | # single_window_padding_width -1
1115 | 
1116 | #: The window padding to use when only a single window is visible (in
1117 | #: pts). Negative values will cause the value of window_padding_width
1118 | #: to be used instead. A single value sets all four sides. Two values
1119 | #: set the vertical and horizontal sides. Three values set top,
1120 | #: horizontal and bottom. Four values set top, right, bottom and left.
1121 | 
1122 | # placement_strategy center
1123 | 
1124 | #: When the window size is not an exact multiple of the cell size, the
1125 | #: cell area of the terminal window will have some extra padding on
1126 | #: the sides. You can control how that padding is distributed with
1127 | #: this option. Using a value of center means the cell area will be
1128 | #: placed centrally. A value of top-left means the padding will be
1129 | #: only at the bottom and right edges. The value can be one of: top-
1130 | #: left, top, top-right, left, center, right, bottom-left, bottom,
1131 | #: bottom-right.
1132 | 
1133 | # active_border_color #00ff00
1134 | 
1135 | #: The color for the border of the active window. Set this to none to
1136 | #: not draw borders around the active window.
1137 | 
1138 | # inactive_border_color #cccccc
1139 | 
1140 | #: The color for the border of inactive windows.
1141 | 
1142 | # bell_border_color #ff5a00
1143 | 
1144 | #: The color for the border of inactive windows in which a bell has
1145 | #: occurred.
1146 | 
1147 | # inactive_text_alpha 1.0
1148 | 
1149 | #: Fade the text in inactive windows by the specified amount (a number
1150 | #: between zero and one, with zero being fully faded).
1151 | 
1152 | hide_window_decorations no
1153 | 
1154 | #: Hide the window decorations (title-bar and window borders) with
1155 | #: yes. On macOS, titlebar-only and titlebar-and-corners can be used
1156 | #: to only hide the titlebar and the rounded corners. Whether this
1157 | #: works and exactly what effect it has depends on the window
1158 | #: manager/operating system. Note that the effects of changing this
1159 | #: option when reloading config are undefined. When using titlebar-
1160 | #: only, it is useful to also set window_margin_width and
1161 | #: placement_strategy to prevent the rounded corners from clipping
1162 | #: text. Or use titlebar-and-corners.
1163 | 
1164 | # window_logo_path none
1165 | 
1166 | #: Path to a logo image. Must be in PNG/JPEG/WEBP/GIF/TIFF/BMP format.
1167 | #: Relative paths are interpreted relative to the kitty config
1168 | #: directory. The logo is displayed in a corner of every kitty window.
1169 | #: The position is controlled by window_logo_position. Individual
1170 | #: windows can be configured to have different logos either using the
1171 | #: launch action or the remote control
1172 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/remote-control/> facility.
1173 | 
1174 | # window_logo_position bottom-right
1175 | 
1176 | #: Where to position the window logo in the window. The value can be
1177 | #: one of: top-left, top, top-right, left, center, right, bottom-left,
1178 | #: bottom, bottom-right.
1179 | 
1180 | # window_logo_alpha 0.5
1181 | 
1182 | #: The amount the logo should be faded into the background. With zero
1183 | #: being fully faded and one being fully opaque.
1184 | 
1185 | # window_logo_scale 0
1186 | 
1187 | #: The percentage (0-100] of the window size to which the logo should
1188 | #: scale. Using a single number means the logo is scaled to that
1189 | #: percentage of the shortest window dimension, while preserving
1190 | #: aspect ratio of the logo image.
1191 | 
1192 | #: Using two numbers means the width and height of the logo are scaled
1193 | #: to the respective percentage of the window's width and height.
1194 | 
1195 | #: Using zero as the percentage disables scaling in that dimension. A
1196 | #: single zero (the default) disables all scaling of the window logo.
1197 | 
1198 | # resize_debounce_time 0.1 0.5
1199 | 
1200 | #: The time to wait (in seconds) before asking the program running in
1201 | #: kitty to resize and redraw the screen during a live resize of the
1202 | #: OS window, when no new resize events have been received, i.e. when
1203 | #: resizing is either paused or finished. On platforms such as macOS,
1204 | #: where the operating system sends events corresponding to the start
1205 | #: and end of a live resize, the second number is used for redraw-
1206 | #: after-pause since kitty can distinguish between a pause and end of
1207 | #: resizing. On such systems the first number is ignored and redraw is
1208 | #: immediate after end of resize. On other systems only the first
1209 | #: number is used so that kitty is "ready" quickly after the end of
1210 | #: resizing, while not also continuously redrawing, to save energy.
1211 | 
1212 | # resize_in_steps no
1213 | 
1214 | #: Resize the OS window in steps as large as the cells, instead of
1215 | #: with the usual pixel accuracy. Combined with initial_window_width
1216 | #: and initial_window_height in number of cells, this option can be
1217 | #: used to keep the margins as small as possible when resizing the OS
1218 | #: window. Note that this does not currently work on Wayland.
1219 | 
1220 | # visual_window_select_characters 1234567890ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ
1221 | 
1222 | #: The list of characters for visual window selection. For example,
1223 | #: for selecting a window to focus on with focus_visible_window. The
1224 | #: value should be a series of unique numbers or alphabets, case
1225 | #: insensitive, from the set 0-9A-Z\-=[];',./\\`. Specify your
1226 | #: preference as a string of characters.
1227 | 
1228 | # confirm_os_window_close -1
1229 | 
1230 | #: Ask for confirmation when closing an OS window or a tab with at
1231 | #: least this number of kitty windows in it by window manager (e.g.
1232 | #: clicking the window close button or pressing the operating system
1233 | #: shortcut to close windows) or by the close_tab action. A value of
1234 | #: zero disables confirmation. This confirmation also applies to
1235 | #: requests to quit the entire application (all OS windows, via the
1236 | #: quit action). Negative values are converted to positive ones,
1237 | #: however, with shell_integration enabled, using negative values
1238 | #: means windows sitting at a shell prompt are not counted, only
1239 | #: windows where some command is currently running. You can also have
1240 | #: backgrounded jobs prevent closing, by adding count-background to
1241 | #: the setting, for example: -1 count-background. Note that if you
1242 | #: want confirmation when closing individual windows, you can map the
1243 | #: close_window_with_confirmation action.
1244 | 
1245 | #: }}}
1246 | 
1247 | #: Tab bar {{{
1248 | 
1249 | # tab_bar_edge bottom
1250 | 
1251 | #: The edge to show the tab bar on, top or bottom.
1252 | 
1253 | # tab_bar_margin_width 0.0
1254 | 
1255 | #: The margin to the left and right of the tab bar (in pts).
1256 | 
1257 | # tab_bar_margin_height 0.0 0.0
1258 | 
1259 | #: The margin above and below the tab bar (in pts). The first number
1260 | #: is the margin between the edge of the OS Window and the tab bar.
1261 | #: The second number is the margin between the tab bar and the
1262 | #: contents of the current tab.
1263 | 
1264 | tab_bar_style powerline
1265 | 
1266 | #: The tab bar style, can be one of:
1267 | 
1268 | #: fade
1269 | #:     Each tab's edges fade into the background color. (See also tab_fade)
1270 | #: slant
1271 | #:     Tabs look like the tabs in a physical file.
1272 | #: separator
1273 | #:     Tabs are separated by a configurable separator. (See also
1274 | #:     tab_separator)
1275 | #: powerline
1276 | #:     Tabs are shown as a continuous line with "fancy" separators.
1277 | #:     (See also tab_powerline_style)
1278 | #: custom
1279 | #:     A user-supplied Python function called draw_tab is loaded from the file
1280 | #:     tab_bar.py in the kitty config directory. For examples of how to
1281 | #:     write such a function, see the functions named draw_tab_with_* in
1282 | #:     kitty's source code: kitty/tab_bar.py. See also
1283 | #:     this discussion <https://github.com/kovidgoyal/kitty/discussions/4447>
1284 | #:     for examples from kitty users.
1285 | #: hidden
1286 | #:     The tab bar is hidden. If you use this, you might want to create
1287 | #:     a mapping for the select_tab action which presents you with a list of
1288 | #:     tabs and allows for easy switching to a tab.
1289 | 
1290 | # tab_bar_filter
1291 | 
1292 | #: A search expression <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/remote-
1293 | #: control/#search-syntax>. Only tabs that match this expression will
1294 | #: be shown in the tab bar. The currently active tab is always shown,
1295 | #: regardless of whether it matches or not. When using this option,
1296 | #: the tab bar may be displayed with less tabs than specified in
1297 | #: tab_bar_min_tabs, as evaluating the filter is expensive and is done
1298 | #: only at display time. This is most useful when using sessions
1299 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/sessions/>. An expression of
1300 | #: session:~ or session:^$ will show only tabs that belong to the
1301 | #: current session or no session. The various tab navigation actions
1302 | #: such as goto_tab, next_tab, previous_tab, etc. are automatically
1303 | #: restricted to work only on matching tabs.
1304 | 
1305 | # tab_bar_align left
1306 | 
1307 | #: The horizontal alignment of the tab bar, can be one of: left,
1308 | #: center, right.
1309 | 
1310 | tab_bar_min_tabs 1
1311 | 
1312 | #: The minimum number of tabs that must exist before the tab bar is
1313 | #: shown.
1314 | 
1315 | # tab_switch_strategy previous
1316 | 
1317 | #: The algorithm to use when switching to a tab when the current tab
1318 | #: is closed. The default of previous will switch to the last used
1319 | #: tab. A value of left will switch to the tab to the left of the
1320 | #: closed tab. A value of right will switch to the tab to the right of
1321 | #: the closed tab. A value of last will switch to the right-most tab.
1322 | 
1323 | # tab_fade 0.25 0.5 0.75 1
1324 | 
1325 | #: Control how each tab fades into the background when using fade for
1326 | #: the tab_bar_style. Each number is an alpha (between zero and one)
1327 | #: that controls how much the corresponding cell fades into the
1328 | #: background, with zero being no fade and one being full fade. You
1329 | #: can change the number of cells used by adding/removing entries to
1330 | #: this list.
1331 | 
1332 | # tab_separator " ┇"
1333 | 
1334 | #: The separator between tabs in the tab bar when using separator as
1335 | #: the tab_bar_style.
1336 | 
1337 | tab_powerline_style round
1338 | 
1339 | #: The powerline separator style between tabs in the tab bar when
1340 | #: using powerline as the tab_bar_style, can be one of: angled,
1341 | #: slanted, round.
1342 | 
1343 | # tab_activity_symbol none
1344 | 
1345 | #: Some text or a Unicode symbol to show on the tab if a window in the
1346 | #: tab that does not have focus has some activity. If you want to use
1347 | #: leading or trailing spaces, surround the text with quotes. See
1348 | #: tab_title_template for how this is rendered.
1349 | 
1350 | # tab_title_max_length 0
1351 | 
1352 | #: The maximum number of cells that can be used to render the text in
1353 | #: a tab. A value of zero means that no limit is applied.
1354 | 
1355 | # tab_title_template "{fmt.fg.red}{bell_symbol}{activity_symbol}{fmt.fg.tab}{tab.last_focused_progress_percent}{title}"
1356 | 
1357 | #: A template to render the tab title. The default just renders the
1358 | #: title with optional symbols for bell and activity. If you wish to
1359 | #: include the tab-index as well, use something like: {index}:{title}.
1360 | #: Useful if you have shortcuts mapped for goto_tab N. If you prefer
1361 | #: to see the index as a superscript, use {sup.index}. All data
1362 | #: available is:
1363 | 
1364 | #: title
1365 | #:     The current tab title.
1366 | #: index
1367 | #:     The tab index usable with goto_tab N goto_tab shortcuts.
1368 | #: layout_name
1369 | #:     The current layout name.
1370 | #: session_name
1371 | #:     The name of the kitty session file from which this tab was created, if any.
1372 | #: active_session_name
1373 | #:     The name of the kitty session file from which the active window in this tab was created, if any.
1374 | #: num_windows
1375 | #:     The number of windows in the tab.
1376 | #: num_window_groups
1377 | #:     The number of window groups (a window group is a window and all of its overlay windows) in the tab.
1378 | #: tab.active_wd
1379 | #:     The working directory of the currently active window in the tab
1380 | #:     (expensive, requires syscall). Use tab.active_oldest_wd to get
1381 | #:     the directory of the oldest foreground process rather than the newest.
1382 | #: tab.active_exe
1383 | #:     The name of the executable running in the foreground of the currently
1384 | #:     active window in the tab (expensive, requires syscall). Use
1385 | #:     tab.active_oldest_exe for the oldest foreground process.
1386 | #: max_title_length
1387 | #:     The maximum title length available.
1388 | #: keyboard_mode
1389 | #:     The name of the current keyboard mode <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/mapping/#modal-mappings> or the empty string if no keyboard mode is active.
1390 | #: tab.last_focused_progress_percent
1391 | #:     If a command running in a window reports the progress for a task, show this progress as a percentage
1392 | #:     from the most recently focused window in the tab. Empty string if no progress is reported.
1393 | #: tab.progress_percent
1394 | #:     If a command running in a window reports the progress for a task, show this progress as a percentage
1395 | #:     from all windows in the tab, averaged. Empty string is no progress is reported.
1396 | #: custom
1397 | #:     This will call a function named draw_title(data) from the file tab_bar.py placed in
1398 | #:     the kitty config directory. The function will be passed a dictionary of data, the same data that
1399 | #:     can be used in this template. It can then perform arbitrarily complex processing and return a string.
1400 | #:     For example: tab_title_template "{custom}" will use the output of the function as the tab title.
1401 | #:     Any print statements in the draw_title() will print to the STDOUT of the kitty process, useful
1402 | #:     for debugging.
1403 | 
1404 | 
1405 | #: Note that formatting is done by Python's string formatting
1406 | #: machinery, so you can use, for instance, {layout_name[:2].upper()}
1407 | #: to show only the first two letters of the layout name, upper-cased.
1408 | #: If you want to style the text, you can use styling directives, for
1409 | #: example:
1410 | #: `{fmt.fg.red}red{fmt.fg.tab}normal{fmt.bg._00FF00}greenbg{fmt.bg.tab}`.
1411 | #: Similarly, for bold and italic:
1412 | #: `{fmt.bold}bold{fmt.nobold}normal{fmt.italic}italic{fmt.noitalic}`.
1413 | #: The 256 eight terminal colors can be used as `fmt.fg.color0`
1414 | #: through `fmt.fg.color255`. Note that for backward compatibility, if
1415 | #: {bell_symbol} or {activity_symbol} are not present in the template,
1416 | #: they are prepended to it.
1417 | 
1418 | # active_tab_title_template none
1419 | 
1420 | #: Template to use for active tabs. If not specified falls back to
1421 | #: tab_title_template.
1422 | 
1423 | # active_tab_foreground   #000
1424 | # active_tab_background   #eee
1425 | # active_tab_font_style   bold-italic
1426 | # inactive_tab_foreground #444
1427 | # inactive_tab_background #999
1428 | # inactive_tab_font_style normal
1429 | 
1430 | #: Tab bar colors and styles.
1431 | 
1432 | # tab_bar_background none
1433 | 
1434 | #: Background color for the tab bar. Defaults to using the terminal
1435 | #: background color.
1436 | 
1437 | # tab_bar_margin_color none
1438 | 
1439 | #: Color for the tab bar margin area. Defaults to using the terminal
1440 | #: background color for margins above and below the tab bar. For side
1441 | #: margins the default color is chosen to match the background color
1442 | #: of the neighboring tab.

1446 | #: Color scheme {{{
1447 | 
1448 | # foreground #dddddd
1449 | # background #000000
1450 | 
1451 | #: The foreground and background colors.
1452 | 
1453 | background_opacity 0.8
1454 | 
1455 | #: The opacity of the background. A number between zero and one, where
1456 | #: one is opaque and zero is fully transparent. This will only work if
1457 | #: supported by the OS (for instance, when using a compositor under
1458 | #: X11). Note that it only sets the background color's opacity in
1459 | #: cells that have the same background color as the default terminal
1460 | #: background, so that things like the status bar in vim, powerline
1461 | #: prompts, etc. still look good. But it means that if you use a color
1462 | #: theme with a background color in your editor, it will not be
1463 | #: rendered as transparent. Instead you should change the default
1464 | #: background color in your kitty config and not use a background
1465 | #: color in the editor color scheme. Or use the escape codes to set
1466 | #: the terminals default colors in a shell script to launch your
1467 | #: editor. See also transparent_background_colors. Be aware that using
1468 | #: a value less than 1.0 is a (possibly significant) performance hit.
1469 | #: When using a low value for this setting, it is desirable that you
1470 | #: set the background color to a color the matches the general color
1471 | #: of the desktop background, for best text rendering.
1472 | 
1473 | #: If you want to dynamically change transparency of windows, set
1474 | #: dynamic_background_opacity to yes (this is off by default as it has
1475 | #: a performance cost). Changing this option when reloading the config
1476 | #: will only work if dynamic_background_opacity was enabled in the
1477 | #: original config.
1478 | 
1479 | # background_blur 0
1480 | 
1481 | #: Set to a positive value to enable background blur (blurring of the
1482 | #: visuals behind a transparent window) on platforms that support it.
1483 | #: Only takes effect when background_opacity is less than one. On
1484 | #: macOS, this will also control the blur radius (amount of blurring).
1485 | #: Setting it to too high a value will cause severe performance issues
1486 | #: and/or rendering artifacts. Usually, values up to 64 work well.
1487 | #: Note that this might cause performance issues, depending on how the
1488 | #: platform implements it, so use with care. Currently supported on
1489 | #: macOS and KDE.
1490 | 
1491 | # transparent_background_colors
1492 | 
1493 | #: A space separated list of upto 7 colors, with opacity. When the
1494 | #: background color of a cell matches one of these colors, it is
1495 | #: rendered semi-transparent using the specified opacity.
1496 | 
1497 | #: Useful in more complex UIs like editors where you could want more
1498 | #: than a single background color to be rendered as transparent, for
1499 | #: instance, for a cursor highlight line background or a highlighted
1500 | #: block. Terminal applications can set this color using The kitty
1501 | #: color control <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/color-stack/#color-
1502 | #: control> escape code.
1503 | 
1504 | #: The syntax for specifying colors is: color@opacity, where the
1505 | #: @opacity part is optional. When unspecified, the value of
1506 | #: background_opacity is used. For example::
1507 | 
1508 | #:     transparent_background_colors red@0.5 #00ff00@0.3
1509 | 
1510 | #: Note that you must also set background_opacity to something less
1511 | #: than 1 for this setting to work properly.
1512 | 
1513 | # dynamic_background_opacity no
1514 | 
1515 | #: Allow changing of the background_opacity dynamically, using either
1516 | #: keyboard shortcuts (increase_background_opacity and
1517 | #: decrease_background_opacity) or the remote control facility.
1518 | #: Changing this option by reloading the config is not supported.
1519 | 
1520 | # background_image none
1521 | 
1522 | #: Path to a background image. Must be in PNG/JPEG/WEBP/TIFF/GIF/BMP
1523 | #: format. Note that when using auto_color_scheme
1524 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/kittens/themes/#auto-color-scheme>
1525 | #: this option is overridden by the color scheme file and must be set
1526 | #: inside it to take effect.
1527 | 
1528 | # background_image_layout tiled
1529 | 
1530 | #: Whether to tile, scale or clamp the background image. The value can
1531 | #: be one of tiled, mirror-tiled, scaled, clamped, centered or
1532 | #: cscaled. The scaled and cscaled values scale the image to the
1533 | #: window size, with cscaled preserving the image aspect ratio. Note
1534 | #: that when using auto_color_scheme
1535 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/kittens/themes/#auto-color-scheme>
1536 | #: this option is overridden by the color scheme file and must be set
1537 | #: inside it to take effect.
1538 | 
1539 | # background_image_linear no
1540 | 
1541 | #: When background image is scaled, whether linear interpolation
1542 | #: should be used. Note that when using auto_color_scheme
1543 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/kittens/themes/#auto-color-scheme>
1544 | #: this option is overridden by the color scheme file and must be set
1545 | #: inside it to take effect.
1546 | 
1547 | # background_tint 0.0
1548 | 
1549 | #: How much to tint the background image by the background color. This
1550 | #: option makes it easier to read the text. Tinting is done using the
1551 | #: current background color for each window. This option applies only
1552 | #: if background_image is set. Note that when using auto_color_scheme
1553 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/kittens/themes/#auto-color-scheme>
1554 | #: this option is overridden by the color scheme file and must be set
1555 | #: inside it to take effect.
1556 | 
1557 | # background_tint_gaps 1.0
1558 | 
1559 | #: How much to tint the background image at the window gaps by the
1560 | #: background color, after applying background_tint. Since this is
1561 | #: multiplicative with background_tint, it can be used to lighten the
1562 | #: tint over the window gaps for a *separated* look. Note that when
1563 | #: using auto_color_scheme
1564 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/kittens/themes/#auto-color-scheme>
1565 | #: this option is overridden by the color scheme file and must be set
1566 | #: inside it to take effect.
1567 | 
1568 | # dim_opacity 0.4
1569 | 
1570 | #: How much to dim text that has the DIM/FAINT attribute set. One
1571 | #: means no dimming and zero means fully dimmed (i.e. invisible).
1572 | 
1573 | # selection_foreground #000000
1574 | # selection_background #fffacd
1575 | 
1576 | #: The foreground and background colors for text selected with the
1577 | #: mouse. Setting both of these to none will cause a "reverse video"
1578 | #: effect for selections, where the selection will be the cell text
1579 | #: color and the text will become the cell background color. Setting
1580 | #: only selection_foreground to none will cause the foreground color
1581 | #: to be used unchanged. Note that these colors can be overridden by
1582 | #: the program running in the terminal.
1583 |
