1658 | #: Advanced {{{
1659 | 
1660 | shell /usr/bin/zsh
1661 | 
1662 | #: The shell program to execute. The default value of . means to use
1663 | #: the value of of the SHELL environment variable or if unset,
1664 | #: whatever shell is set as the default shell for the current user.
1665 | #: Note that on macOS if you change this, you might need to add
1666 | #: --login and --interactive to ensure that the shell starts in
1667 | #: interactive mode and reads its startup rc files. Environment
1668 | #: variables are expanded in this setting.
1669 | 
1670 | # editor .
1671 | 
1672 | #: The terminal based text editor (such as vim or nano) to use when
1673 | #: editing the kitty config file or similar tasks.
1674 | 
1675 | #: The default value of . means to use the environment variables
1676 | #: VISUAL and EDITOR in that order. If these variables aren't set,
1677 | #: kitty will run your shell ($SHELL -l -i -c env) to see if your
1678 | #: shell startup rc files set VISUAL or EDITOR. If that doesn't work,
1679 | #: kitty will cycle through various known editors (vim, emacs, etc.)
1680 | #: and take the first one that exists on your system.
1681 | 
1682 | # close_on_child_death no
1683 | 
1684 | #: Close the window when the child process (usually the shell) exits.
1685 | #: With the default value no, the terminal will remain open when the
1686 | #: child exits as long as there are still other processes outputting
1687 | #: to the terminal (for example disowned or backgrounded processes).
1688 | #: When enabled with yes, the window will close as soon as the child
1689 | #: process exits. Note that setting it to yes means that any
1690 | #: background processes still using the terminal can fail silently
1691 | #: because their stdout/stderr/stdin no longer work.
1692 | 
1693 | # remote_control_password
1694 | 
1695 | #: Allow other programs to control kitty using passwords. This option
1696 | #: can be specified multiple times to add multiple passwords. If no
1697 | #: passwords are present kitty will ask the user for permission if a
1698 | #: program tries to use remote control with a password. A password can
1699 | #: also *optionally* be associated with a set of allowed remote
1700 | #: control actions. For example::
1701 | 
1702 | #:     remote_control_password "my passphrase" get-colors set-colors focus-window focus-tab
1703 | 
1704 | #: Only the specified actions will be allowed when using this
1705 | #: password. Glob patterns can be used too, for example::
1706 | 
1707 | #:     remote_control_password "my passphrase" set-tab-* resize-*
1708 | 
1709 | #: To get a list of available actions, run::
1710 | 
1711 | #:     kitten @ --help
1712 | 
1713 | #: A set of actions to be allowed when no password is sent can be
1714 | #: specified by using an empty password. For example::
1715 | 
1716 | #:     remote_control_password "" *-colors
1717 | 
1718 | #: Finally, the path to a python module can be specified that provides
1719 | #: a function is_cmd_allowed that is used to check every remote
1720 | #: control command. For example::
1721 | 
1722 | #:     remote_control_password "my passphrase" my_rc_command_checker.py
1723 | 
1724 | #: Relative paths are resolved from the kitty configuration directory.
1725 | #: See rc_custom_auth <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/remote-
1726 | #: control/#rc-custom-auth> for details.
1727 | 
1728 | # allow_remote_control no
1729 | 
1730 | #: Allow other programs to control kitty. If you turn this on, other
1731 | #: programs can control all aspects of kitty, including sending text
1732 | #: to kitty windows, opening new windows, closing windows, reading the
1733 | #: content of windows, etc. Note that this even works over SSH
1734 | #: connections. The default setting of no prevents any form of remote
1735 | #: control. The meaning of the various values are:
1736 | 
1737 | #: password
1738 | #:     Remote control requests received over both the TTY device and the socket
1739 | #:     are confirmed based on passwords, see remote_control_password.
1740 | 
1741 | #: socket-only
1742 | #:     Remote control requests received over a socket are accepted
1743 | #:     unconditionally. Requests received over the TTY are denied.
1744 | #:     See listen_on.
1745 | 
1746 | #: socket
1747 | #:     Remote control requests received over a socket are accepted
1748 | #:     unconditionally. Requests received over the TTY are confirmed based on
1749 | #:     password.
1750 | 
1751 | #: no
1752 | #:     Remote control is completely disabled.
1753 | 
1754 | #: yes
1755 | #:     Remote control requests are always accepted.
1756 | 
1757 | # listen_on none
1758 | 
1759 | #: Listen to the specified socket for remote control connections. Note
1760 | #: that this will apply to all kitty instances. It can be overridden
1761 | #: by the kitty --listen-on command line option. For UNIX sockets,
1762 | #: such as unix:${TEMP}/mykitty or unix:@mykitty (on Linux).
1763 | #: Environment variables are expanded and relative paths are resolved
1764 | #: with respect to the temporary directory. If {kitty_pid} is present,
1765 | #: then it is replaced by the PID of the kitty process, otherwise the
1766 | #: PID of the kitty process is appended to the value, with a hyphen.
1767 | #: For TCP sockets such as tcp:localhost:0 a random port is always
1768 | #: used even if a non-zero port number is specified.  See the help for
1769 | #: kitty --listen-on for more details. Note that this will be ignored
1770 | #: unless allow_remote_control is set to either: yes, socket or
1771 | #: socket-only. Changing this option by reloading the config is not
1772 | #: supported.
1773 | 
1774 | # env
1775 | 
1776 | #: Specify the environment variables to be set in all child processes.
1777 | #: Using the name with an equal sign (e.g. env VAR=) will set it to
1778 | #: the empty string. Specifying only the name (e.g. env VAR) will
1779 | #: remove the variable from the child process' environment. Note that
1780 | #: environment variables are expanded recursively, for example::
1781 | 
1782 | #:     env VAR1=a
1783 | #:     env VAR2=${HOME}/${VAR1}/b
1784 | 
1785 | #: The value of VAR2 will be <path to home directory>/a/b.
1786 | 
1787 | # filter_notification
1788 | 
1789 | #: Specify rules to filter out notifications sent by applications
1790 | #: running in kitty. Can be specified multiple times to create
1791 | #: multiple filter rules. A rule specification is of the form
1792 | #: field:regexp. A filter rule can match on any of the fields: title,
1793 | #: body, app, type. The special value of all filters out all
1794 | #: notifications. Rules can be combined using Boolean operators. Some
1795 | #: examples::
1796 | 
1797 | #:     filter_notification title:hello or body:"abc.*def"
1798 | #:     # filter out notification from vim except for ones about updates, (?i)
1799 | #:     # makes matching case insensitive.
1800 | #:     filter_notification app:"[ng]?vim" and not body:"(?i)update"
1801 | #:     # filter out all notifications
1802 | #:     filter_notification all
1803 | 
1804 | #: The field app is the name of the application sending the
1805 | #: notification and type is the type of the notification. Not all
1806 | #: applications will send these fields, so you can also match on the
1807 | #: title and body of the notification text. More sophisticated
1808 | #: programmatic filtering and custom actions on notifications can be
1809 | #: done by creating a notifications.py file in the kitty config
1810 | #: directory (~/.config/kitty). An annotated sample is available
1811 | #: <https://github.com/kovidgoyal/kitty/blob/master/docs/notifications.py>.
1812 | 
1813 | # watcher
1814 | 
1815 | #: Path to python file which will be loaded for watchers
1816 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/launch/#watchers>. Can be
1817 | #: specified more than once to load multiple watchers. The watchers
1818 | #: will be added to every kitty window. Relative paths are resolved
1819 | #: relative to the kitty config directory. Note that reloading the
1820 | #: config will only affect windows created after the reload.
1821 | 
1822 | # exe_search_path
1823 | 
1824 | #: Control where kitty finds the programs to run. The default search
1825 | #: order is: First search the system wide PATH, then ~/.local/bin and
1826 | #: ~/bin. If still not found, the PATH defined in the login shell
1827 | #: after sourcing all its startup files is tried. Finally, if present,
1828 | #: the PATH specified by the env option is tried.
1829 | 
1830 | #: This option allows you to prepend, append, or remove paths from
1831 | #: this search order. It can be specified multiple times for multiple
1832 | #: paths. A simple path will be prepended to the search order. A path
1833 | #: that starts with the + sign will be append to the search order,
1834 | #: after ~/bin above. A path that starts with the - sign will be
1835 | #: removed from the entire search order. For example::
1836 | 
1837 | #:     exe_search_path /some/prepended/path
1838 | #:     exe_search_path +/some/appended/path
1839 | #:     exe_search_path -/some/excluded/path
1840 | 
1841 | # update_check_interval 24
1842 | 
1843 | #: The interval to periodically check if an update to kitty is
1844 | #: available (in hours). If an update is found, a system notification
1845 | #: is displayed informing you of the available update. The default is
1846 | #: to check every 24 hours, set to zero to disable. Update checking is
1847 | #: only done by the official binary builds. Distro packages or source
1848 | #: builds do not do update checking. Changing this option by reloading
1849 | #: the config is not supported.
1850 | 
1851 | # startup_session none
1852 | 
1853 | #: Path to a session file to use for all kitty instances. Can be
1854 | #: overridden by using the kitty --session =none command line option
1855 | #: for individual instances. See sessions
1856 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/sessions/> in the kitty
1857 | #: documentation for details. Note that relative paths are interpreted
1858 | #: with respect to the kitty config directory. Environment variables
1859 | #: in the path are expanded. Changing this option by reloading the
1860 | #: config is not supported. Note that if kitty is invoked with command
1861 | #: line arguments specifying a command to run, this option is ignored.
1862 | 
1863 | # clipboard_control write-clipboard write-primary read-clipboard-ask read-primary-ask
1864 | 
1865 | #: Allow programs running in kitty to read and write from the
1866 | #: clipboard. You can control exactly which actions are allowed. The
1867 | #: possible actions are: write-clipboard, read-clipboard, write-
1868 | #: primary, read-primary, read-clipboard-ask, read-primary-ask. The
1869 | #: default is to allow writing to the clipboard and primary selection
1870 | #: and to ask for permission when a program tries to read from the
1871 | #: clipboard. Note that disabling the read confirmation is a security
1872 | #: risk as it means that any program, even the ones running on a
1873 | #: remote server via SSH can read your clipboard. See also
1874 | #: clipboard_max_size.
1875 | 
1876 | # clipboard_max_size 512
1877 | 
1878 | #: The maximum size (in MB) of data from programs running in kitty
1879 | #: that will be stored for writing to the system clipboard. A value of
1880 | #: zero means no size limit is applied. See also clipboard_control.
1881 | 
1882 | # file_transfer_confirmation_bypass
1883 | 
1884 | #: The password that can be supplied to the file transfer kitten
1885 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/kittens/transfer/> to skip the
1886 | #: transfer confirmation prompt. This should only be used when
1887 | #: initiating transfers from trusted computers, over trusted networks
1888 | #: or encrypted transports, as it allows any programs running on the
1889 | #: remote machine to read/write to the local filesystem, without
1890 | #: permission.
1891 | 
1892 | # allow_hyperlinks yes
1893 | 
1894 | #: Process hyperlink escape sequences (OSC 8). If disabled OSC 8
1895 | #: escape sequences are ignored. Otherwise they become clickable
1896 | #: links, that you can click with the mouse or by using the hints
1897 | #: kitten <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/kittens/hints/>. The
1898 | #: special value of ask means that kitty will ask before opening the
1899 | #: link when clicked.
1900 | 
1901 | # shell_integration enabled
1902 | 
1903 | #: Enable shell integration on supported shells. This enables features
1904 | #: such as jumping to previous prompts, browsing the output of the
1905 | #: previous command in a pager, etc. on supported shells. Set to
1906 | #: disabled to turn off shell integration, completely. It is also
1907 | #: possible to disable individual features, set to a space separated
1908 | #: list of these values: no-rc, no-cursor, no-title, no-cwd, no-
1909 | #: prompt-mark, no-complete, no-sudo. See Shell integration
1910 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/shell-integration/> for details.
1911 | 
1912 | # allow_cloning ask
1913 | 
1914 | #: Control whether programs running in the terminal can request new
1915 | #: windows to be created. The canonical example is clone-in-kitty
1916 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/shell-integration/#clone-shell>.
1917 | #: By default, kitty will ask for permission for each clone request.
1918 | #: Allowing cloning unconditionally gives programs running in the
1919 | #: terminal (including over SSH) permission to execute arbitrary code,
1920 | #: as the user who is running the terminal, on the computer that the
1921 | #: terminal is running on.
1922 | 
1923 | # clone_source_strategies venv,conda,env_var,path
1924 | 
1925 | #: Control what shell code is sourced when running clone-in-kitty in
1926 | #: the newly cloned window. The supported strategies are:
1927 | 
1928 | #: venv
1929 | #:     Source the file $VIRTUAL_ENV/bin/activate. This is used by the
1930 | #:     Python stdlib venv module and allows cloning venvs automatically.
1931 | #: conda
1932 | #:     Run conda activate $CONDA_DEFAULT_ENV. This supports the virtual
1933 | #:     environments created by conda.
1934 | #: env_var
1935 | #:     Execute the contents of the environment variable
1936 | #:     KITTY_CLONE_SOURCE_CODE with eval.
1937 | #: path
1938 | #:     Source the file pointed to by the environment variable
1939 | #:     KITTY_CLONE_SOURCE_PATH.
1940 | 
1941 | #: This option must be a comma separated list of the above values.
1942 | #: Only the first valid match, in the order specified, is sourced.
1943 | 
1944 | # notify_on_cmd_finish never
1945 | 
1946 | #: Show a desktop notification when a long-running command finishes
1947 | #: (needs shell_integration). The possible values are:
1948 | 
1949 | #: never
1950 | #:     Never send a notification.
1951 | 
1952 | #: unfocused
1953 | #:     Only send a notification when the window does not have keyboard focus.
1954 | 
1955 | #: invisible
1956 | #:     Only send a notification when the window both is unfocused and not visible
1957 | #:     to the user, for example, because it is in an inactive tab or its OS window
1958 | #:     is not currently visible (on platforms that support OS window visibility querying
1959 | #:     this considers an OS Window visible iff it is active).
1960 | 
1961 | #: always
1962 | #:     Always send a notification, regardless of window state.
1963 | 
1964 | #: There are two optional arguments:
1965 | 
1966 | #: First, the minimum duration for what is considered a long running
1967 | #: command. The default is 5 seconds. Specify a second argument to set
1968 | #: the duration. For example: invisible 15. Do not set the value too
1969 | #: small, otherwise a command that launches a new OS Window and exits
1970 | #: will spam a notification.
1971 | 
1972 | #: Second, the action to perform. The default is notify. The possible
1973 | #: values are:
1974 | 
1975 | #: notify
1976 | #:     Send a desktop notification. The subsequent arguments are optional and specify when
1977 | #:     the notification is automatically cleared. The set of possible events when the notification is
1978 | #:     cleared are: focus and next. focus means that when the notification
1979 | #:     policy is unfocused or invisible the notification is automatically cleared
1980 | #:     when the window regains focus. The value of next means that the previous notification
1981 | #:     is cleared when the next notification is shown. The default when no arguments are specified
1982 | #:     is: focus next.
1983 | 
1984 | #: bell
1985 | #:     Ring the terminal bell.
1986 | 
1987 | #: notify-bell
1988 | #:     Send a desktop notification and ring the terminal bell.
1989 | #:     The arguments are the same as for `notify`.
1990 | 
1991 | #: command
1992 | #:     Run a custom command. All subsequent arguments are the cmdline to run.
1993 | 
1994 | #: Some more examples::
1995 | 
1996 | #:     # Send a notification when a command takes more than 5 seconds in an unfocused window
1997 | #:     notify_on_cmd_finish unfocused
1998 | #:     # Send a notification when a command takes more than 10 seconds in a invisible window
1999 | #:     notify_on_cmd_finish invisible 10.0
2000 | #:     # Ring a bell when a command takes more than 10 seconds in a invisible window
2001 | #:     notify_on_cmd_finish invisible 10.0 bell
2002 | #:     # Run 'notify-send' when a command takes more than 10 seconds in a invisible window
2003 | #:     # Here %c is replaced by the current command line and %s by the job exit code
2004 | #:     notify_on_cmd_finish invisible 10.0 command notify-send "job finished with status: %s" %c
2005 | #:     # Do not clear previous notification when next command finishes or window regains focus
2006 | #:     notify_on_cmd_finish invisible 5.0 notify
2007 | 
2008 | # term xterm-kitty
2009 | 
2010 | #: The value of the TERM environment variable to set. Changing this
2011 | #: can break many terminal programs, only change it if you know what
2012 | #: you are doing, not because you read some advice on "Stack Overflow"
2013 | #: to change it. The TERM variable is used by various programs to get
2014 | #: information about the capabilities and behavior of the terminal. If
2015 | #: you change it, depending on what programs you run, and how
2016 | #: different the terminal you are changing it to is, various things
2017 | #: from key-presses, to colors, to various advanced features may not
2018 | #: work. Changing this option by reloading the config will only affect
2019 | #: newly created windows.
2020 | 
2021 | # terminfo_type path
2022 | 
2023 | #: The value of the TERMINFO environment variable to set. This
2024 | #: variable is used by programs running in the terminal to search for
2025 | #: terminfo databases. The default value of path causes kitty to set
2026 | #: it to a filesystem location containing the kitty terminfo database.
2027 | #: A value of direct means put the entire database into the env var
2028 | #: directly. This can be useful when connecting to containers, for
2029 | #: example. But, note that not all software supports this. A value of
2030 | #: none means do not touch the variable.
2031 | 
2032 | # forward_stdio no
2033 | 
2034 | #: Forward STDOUT and STDERR of the kitty process to child processes.
2035 | #: This is useful for debugging as it allows child processes to print
2036 | #: to kitty's STDOUT directly. For example, echo hello world
2037 | #: >&$KITTY_STDIO_FORWARDED in a shell will print to the parent
2038 | #: kitty's STDOUT. Sets the KITTY_STDIO_FORWARDED=fdnum environment
2039 | #: variable so child processes know about the forwarding. Note that on
2040 | #: macOS this prevents the shell from being run via the login utility
2041 | #: so getlogin() will not work in programs run in this session.
2042 | 
2043 | # menu_map
2044 | 
2045 | #: Specify entries for various menus in kitty. Currently only the
2046 | #: global menubar on macOS is supported. For example::
2047 | 
2048 | #:    menu_map global "Actions::Launch something special" launch --hold --type=os-window sh -c "echo hello world"
2049 | 
2050 | #: This will create a menu entry named "Launch something special" in
2051 | #: an "Actions" menu in the macOS global menubar. Sub-menus can be
2052 | #: created by adding more levels separated by the :: characters.
2053 | 
2054 | #: }}}
2055 | 
2056 | #: OS specific tweaks {{{
2057 | 
2058 | # wayland_titlebar_color system
2059 | 
2060 | #: The color of the kitty window's titlebar on Wayland systems with
2061 | #: client side window decorations such as GNOME. A value of system
2062 | #: means to use the default system colors, a value of background means
2063 | #: to use the background color of the currently active kitty window
2064 | #: and finally you can use an arbitrary color, such as #12af59 or red.
2065 | 
2066 | # macos_titlebar_color system
2067 | 
2068 | #: The color of the kitty window's titlebar on macOS. A value of
2069 | #: system means to use the default system color, light or dark can
2070 | #: also be used to set it explicitly. A value of background means to
2071 | #: use the background color of the currently active window and finally
2072 | #: you can use an arbitrary color, such as #12af59 or red.
2073 | 
2074 | # macos_option_as_alt no
2075 | 
2076 | #: Use the Option key as an Alt key on macOS. With this set to no,
2077 | #: kitty will use the macOS native Option+Key to enter Unicode
2078 | #: character behavior. This will break any Alt+Key keyboard shortcuts
2079 | #: in your terminal programs, but you can use the macOS Unicode input
2080 | #: technique. You can use the values: left, right or both to use only
2081 | #: the left, right or both Option keys as Alt, instead. Note that
2082 | #: kitty itself always treats Option the same as Alt. This means you
2083 | #: cannot use this option to configure different kitty shortcuts for
2084 | #: Option+Key vs. Alt+Key. Also, any kitty shortcuts using
2085 | #: Option/Alt+Key will take priority, so that any such key presses
2086 | #: will not be passed to terminal programs running inside kitty.
2087 | #: Changing this option by reloading the config is not supported.
2088 | 
2089 | # macos_hide_from_tasks no
2090 | 
2091 | #: Hide the kitty window from running tasks on macOS (⌘+Tab and the
2092 | #: Dock). Changing this option by reloading the config is not
2093 | #: supported.
2094 | 
2095 | # macos_quit_when_last_window_closed no
2096 | 
2097 | #: Have kitty quit when all the top-level windows are closed on macOS.
2098 | #: By default, kitty will stay running, even with no open windows, as
2099 | #: is the expected behavior on macOS.
2100 | 
2101 | # macos_window_resizable yes
2102 | 
2103 | #: Disable this if you want kitty top-level OS windows to not be
2104 | #: resizable on macOS.
2105 | 
2106 | # macos_thicken_font 0
2107 | 
2108 | #: Draw an extra border around the font with the given width, to
2109 | #: increase legibility at small font sizes on macOS. For example, a
2110 | #: value of 0.75 will result in rendering that looks similar to sub-
2111 | #: pixel antialiasing at common font sizes. Note that in modern kitty,
2112 | #: this option is obsolete (although still supported). Consider using
2113 | #: text_composition_strategy instead.
2114 | 
2115 | # macos_traditional_fullscreen no
2116 | 
2117 | #: Use the macOS traditional full-screen transition, that is faster,
2118 | #: but less pretty.
2119 | 
2120 | # macos_show_window_title_in all
2121 | 
2122 | #: Control where the window title is displayed on macOS. A value of
2123 | #: window will show the title of the currently active window at the
2124 | #: top of the macOS window. A value of menubar will show the title of
2125 | #: the currently active window in the macOS global menu bar, making
2126 | #: use of otherwise wasted space. A value of all will show the title
2127 | #: in both places, and none hides the title. See
2128 | #: macos_menubar_title_max_length for how to control the length of the
2129 | #: title in the menu bar.
2130 | 
2131 | # macos_menubar_title_max_length 0
2132 | 
2133 | #: The maximum number of characters from the window title to show in
2134 | #: the macOS global menu bar. Values less than one means that there is
2135 | #: no maximum limit.
2136 | 
2137 | # macos_custom_beam_cursor no
2138 | 
2139 | #: Use a custom mouse cursor for macOS that is easier to see on both
2140 | #: light and dark backgrounds. Nowadays, the default macOS cursor
2141 | #: already comes with a white border. WARNING: this might make your
2142 | #: mouse cursor invisible on dual GPU machines. Changing this option
2143 | #: by reloading the config is not supported.
2144 | 
2145 | # macos_colorspace srgb
2146 | 
2147 | #: The colorspace in which to interpret terminal colors. The default
2148 | #: of srgb will cause colors to match those seen in web browsers. The
2149 | #: value of default will use whatever the native colorspace of the
2150 | #: display is. The value of displayp3 will use Apple's special
2151 | #: snowflake display P3 color space, which will result in over
2152 | #: saturated (brighter) colors with some color shift. Reloading
2153 | #: configuration will change this value only for newly created OS
2154 | #: windows.
2155 | 
2156 | # linux_display_server auto
2157 | 
2158 | #: Choose between Wayland and X11 backends. By default, an appropriate
2159 | #: backend based on the system state is chosen automatically. Set it
2160 | #: to x11 or wayland to force the choice. Changing this option by
2161 | #: reloading the config is not supported.
2162 | 
2163 | # wayland_enable_ime yes
2164 | 
2165 | #: Enable Input Method Extension on Wayland. This is typically used
2166 | #: for inputting text in East Asian languages. However, its
2167 | #: implementation in Wayland is often buggy and introduces latency
2168 | #: into the input loop, so disable this if you know you dont need it.
2169 | #: Changing this option by reloading the config is not supported, it
2170 | #: will not have any effect.
2171 | 
2172 | #: }}}
2173 | 
2174 | #: Keyboard shortcuts {{{
2175 | 
2176 | #: Keys are identified simply by their lowercase Unicode characters.
2177 | #: For example: a for the A key, [ for the left square bracket key,
2178 | #: etc. For functional keys, such as Enter or Escape, the names are
2179 | #: present at Functional key definitions
2180 | #: <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/keyboard-protocol/#functional>.
2181 | #: For modifier keys, the names are ctrl (control, ⌃), shift (⇧), alt
2182 | #: (opt, option, ⌥), super (cmd, command, ⌘).
2183 | 
2184 | #: Simple shortcut mapping is done with the map directive. For full
2185 | #: details on advanced mapping including modal and per application
2186 | #: maps, see mapping <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/mapping/>. Some
2187 | #: quick examples to illustrate common tasks::
2188 | 
2189 | #:     # unmap a keyboard shortcut, passing it to the program running in kitty
2190 | #:     map kitty_mod+space
2191 | #:     # completely ignore a keyboard event
2192 | #:     map ctrl+alt+f1 discard_event
2193 | #:     # combine multiple actions
2194 | #:     map kitty_mod+e combine : new_window : next_layout
2195 | #:     # multi-key shortcuts
2196 | #:     map ctrl+x>ctrl+y>z action
2197 | 
2198 | #: The full list of actions that can be mapped to key presses is
2199 | #: available here <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/actions/>.
2200 | 
2201 | # kitty_mod ctrl+shift
2202 | 
2203 | #: Special modifier key alias for default shortcuts. You can change
2204 | #: the value of this option to alter all default shortcuts that use
2205 | #: kitty_mod.
2206 | 
2207 | # clear_all_shortcuts no
2208 | 
2209 | #: Remove all shortcut definitions up to this point. Useful, for
2210 | #: instance, to remove the default shortcuts.
2211 | 
2212 | # action_alias
2213 | 
2214 | #: E.g. action_alias launch_tab launch --type=tab --cwd=current
2215 | 
2216 | #: Define action aliases to avoid repeating the same options in
2217 | #: multiple mappings. Aliases can be defined for any action and will
2218 | #: be expanded recursively. For example, the above alias allows you to
2219 | #: create mappings to launch a new tab in the current working
2220 | #: directory without duplication::
2221 | 
2222 | #:     map f1 launch_tab vim
2223 | #:     map f2 launch_tab emacs
2224 | 
2225 | #: Similarly, to alias kitten invocation::
2226 | 
2227 | #:     action_alias hints kitten hints --hints-offset=0
2228 | 
2229 | # kitten_alias
2230 | 
2231 | #: E.g. kitten_alias hints hints --hints-offset=0
2232 | 
2233 | #: Like action_alias above, but specifically for kittens. Generally,
2234 | #: prefer to use action_alias. This option is a legacy version,
2235 | #: present for backwards compatibility. It causes all invocations of
2236 | #: the aliased kitten to be substituted. So the example above will
2237 | #: cause all invocations of the hints kitten to have the --hints-
2238 | #: offset=0 option applied.
2239 | 
2240 | #: Clipboard {{{
2241 | 
2242 | #: Copy to clipboard
2243 | 
2244 | # map kitty_mod+c copy_to_clipboard
2245 | 
2246 | #::  There is also a copy_or_interrupt action that can be optionally
2247 | #::  mapped to Ctrl+C. It will copy only if there is a selection and
2248 | #::  send an interrupt otherwise. Similarly,
2249 | #::  copy_and_clear_or_interrupt will copy and clear the selection or
2250 | #::  send an interrupt if there is no selection. The copy_or_noop
2251 | #::  action will copy if there is a selection and pass the key through
2252 | #::  to the application running in the terminal if there is no
2253 | #::  selection.
2254 | 
2255 | #: Copy to clipboard or pass through
2256 | 
2257 | # map cmd+c copy_or_noop
2258 | 
2259 | #: Paste from clipboard
2260 | 
2261 | # map kitty_mod+v paste_from_clipboard
2262 | # map cmd+v       paste_from_clipboard
2263 | 
2264 | #: Paste from selection
2265 | 
2266 | # map kitty_mod+s  paste_from_selection
2267 | # map shift+insert paste_from_selection
2268 | 
2269 | #: Pass selection to program
2270 | 
2271 | # map kitty_mod+o pass_selection_to_program
2272 | 
2273 | #::  You can also pass the contents of the current selection to any
2274 | #::  program with pass_selection_to_program. By default, the system's
2275 | #::  open program is used, but you can specify your own, the selection
2276 | #::  will be passed as a command line argument to the program. For
2277 | #::  example::
2278 | 
2279 | #::      map kitty_mod+o pass_selection_to_program firefox
2280 | 
2281 | #::  You can pass the current selection to a terminal program running
2282 | #::  in a new kitty window, by using the @selection placeholder::
2283 | 
2284 | #::      map kitty_mod+y new_window less @selection
2285 | 
2286 | #: }}}
2287 | 
2288 | #: Scrolling {{{
2289 | 
2290 | #: Scroll line up
2291 | 
2292 | # map kitty_mod+up    scroll_line_up
2293 | # map kitty_mod+k     scroll_line_up
2294 | # map opt+cmd+page_up scroll_line_up
2295 | # map cmd+up          scroll_line_up
2296 | 
2297 | #: Scroll line down
2298 | 
2299 | # map kitty_mod+down    scroll_line_down
2300 | # map kitty_mod+j       scroll_line_down
2301 | # map opt+cmd+page_down scroll_line_down
2302 | # map cmd+down          scroll_line_down
2303 | 
2304 | #: Scroll page up
2305 | 
2306 | # map kitty_mod+page_up scroll_page_up
2307 | # map cmd+page_up       scroll_page_up
2308 | 
2309 | #: Scroll page down
2310 | 
2311 | # map kitty_mod+page_down scroll_page_down
2312 | # map cmd+page_down       scroll_page_down
2313 | 
2314 | #: Scroll to top
2315 | 
2316 | # map kitty_mod+home scroll_home
2317 | # map cmd+home       scroll_home
2318 | 
2319 | #: Scroll to bottom
2320 | 
2321 | # map kitty_mod+end scroll_end
2322 | # map cmd+end       scroll_end
2323 | 
2324 | #: Scroll to previous shell prompt
2325 | 
2326 | # map kitty_mod+z scroll_to_prompt -1
2327 | 
2328 | #::  Use a parameter of 0 for scroll_to_prompt to scroll to the last
2329 | #::  jumped to or the last clicked position. Requires shell
2330 | #::  integration <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/shell-integration/>
2331 | #::  to work.
2332 | 
2333 | #: Scroll to next shell prompt
2334 | 
2335 | # map kitty_mod+x scroll_to_prompt 1
2336 | 
2337 | #: Browse scrollback buffer in pager
2338 | 
2339 | # map kitty_mod+h show_scrollback
2340 | 
2341 | #::  You can pipe the contents of the current screen and history
2342 | #::  buffer as STDIN to an arbitrary program using launch --stdin-
2343 | #::  source. For example, the following opens the scrollback buffer in
2344 | #::  less in an overlay window::
2345 | 
2346 | #::      map f1 launch --stdin-source=@screen_scrollback --stdin-add-formatting --type=overlay less +G -R
2347 | 
2348 | #::  For more details on piping screen and buffer contents to external
2349 | #::  programs, see launch <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/launch/>.
2350 | 
2351 | #: Browse output of the last shell command in pager
2352 | 
2353 | # map kitty_mod+g show_last_command_output
2354 | 
2355 | #::  You can also define additional shortcuts to get the command
2356 | #::  output. For example, to get the first command output on screen::
2357 | 
2358 | #::      map f1 show_first_command_output_on_screen
2359 | 
2360 | #::  To get the command output that was last accessed by a keyboard
2361 | #::  action or mouse action::
2362 | 
2363 | #::      map f1 show_last_visited_command_output
2364 | 
2365 | #::  You can pipe the output of the last command run in the shell
2366 | #::  using the launch action. For example, the following opens the
2367 | #::  output in less in an overlay window::
2368 | 
2369 | #::      map f1 launch --stdin-source=@last_cmd_output --stdin-add-formatting --type=overlay less +G -R
2370 | 
2371 | #::  To get the output of the first command on the screen, use
2372 | #::  @first_cmd_output_on_screen. To get the output of the last jumped
2373 | #::  to command, use @last_visited_cmd_output.
2374 | 
2375 | #::  Requires shell integration
2376 | #::  <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/shell-integration/> to work.
2377 | 
2378 | #: }}}
2379 | 
2380 | #: Window management {{{
2381 | 
2382 | #: New window
2383 | 
2384 | # map kitty_mod+enter new_window
2385 | # map cmd+enter       new_window
2386 | 
2387 | #::  You can open a new kitty window running an arbitrary program, for
2388 | #::  example::
2389 | 
2390 | #::      map kitty_mod+y launch mutt
2391 | 
2392 | #::  You can open a new window with the current working directory set
2393 | #::  to the working directory of the current window using::
2394 | 
2395 | #::      map ctrl+alt+enter launch --cwd=current
2396 | 
2397 | #::  You can open a new window that is allowed to control kitty via
2398 | #::  the kitty remote control facility with launch --allow-remote-
2399 | #::  control. Any programs running in that window will be allowed to
2400 | #::  control kitty. For example::
2401 | 
2402 | #::      map ctrl+enter launch --allow-remote-control some_program
2403 | 
2404 | #::  You can open a new window next to the currently active window or
2405 | #::  as the first window, with::
2406 | 
2407 | #::      map ctrl+n launch --location=neighbor
2408 | #::      map ctrl+f launch --location=first
2409 | 
2410 | #::  For more details, see launch
2411 | #::  <https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/launch/>.
2412 | 
2413 | #: New OS window
2414 | 
2415 | # map kitty_mod+n new_os_window
2416 | # map cmd+n       new_os_window
2417 | 
2418 | #::  Works like new_window above, except that it opens a top-level OS
2419 | #::  window. In particular you can use new_os_window_with_cwd to open
2420 | #::  a window with the current working directory.
2421 | 
2422 | #: Close window
2423 | 
2424 | # map kitty_mod+w close_window
2425 | # map shift+cmd+d close_window
2426 | 
2427 | #: Next window
2428 | 
2429 | # map kitty_mod+] next_window
2430 | 
2431 | #: Previous window
2432 | 
2433 | # map kitty_mod+[ previous_window
2434 | 
2435 | #: Move window forward
2436 | 
2437 | # map kitty_mod+f move_window_forward
2438 |

2765 | #: Reset the terminal

2767 | # map kitty_mod+delete clear_terminal reset active
2768 | # map opt+cmd+r        clear_terminal reset active
2769 | 
2770 | #::  You can create shortcuts to clear/reset the terminal. For
2771 | #::  example::
2772 | 
2773 | #::      # Reset the terminal
2774 | #::      map f1 clear_terminal reset active
2775 | #::      # Clear the terminal screen by erasing all contents
2776 | #::      map f1 clear_terminal clear active
2777 | #::      # Clear the terminal scrollback by erasing it
2778 | #::      map f1 clear_terminal scrollback active
2779 | #::      # Scroll the contents of the screen into the scrollback
2780 | #::      map f1 clear_terminal scroll active
2781 | #::      # Clear everything on screen up to the line with the cursor or the start of the current prompt (needs shell integration)
2782 | #::      map f1 clear_terminal to_cursor active
2783 | #::      # Same as above except cleared lines are moved into scrollback
2784 | #::      map f1 clear_terminal to_cursor_scroll active
2785 | #::      # Erase the last command and its output (needs shell integration to work)
2786 | #::      map f1 clear_terminal last_command active
2787 | 
2788 | #::  If you want to operate on all kitty windows instead of just the
2789 | #::  current one, use all instead of active.
2790 | 
2791 | #::  Some useful functions that can be defined in the shell rc files
2792 | #::  to perform various kinds of clearing of the current window:
2793 | 
2794 | #::  .. code-block:: sh
2795 | 
2796 | #::      clear-only-screen() {
2797 | #::          printf "\e[H\e[2J"
2798 | #::      }
2799 | 
2800 | #::      clear-screen-and-scrollback() {
2801 | #::          printf "\e[H\e[3J"
2802 | #::      }
2803 | 
2804 | #::      clear-screen-saving-contents-in-scrollback() {
2805 | #::          printf "\e[H\e[22J"
2806 | #::      }
2807 | 
2808 | #::  For instance, using these escape codes, it is possible to remap
2809 | #::  Ctrl+L to both scroll the current screen contents into the
2810 | #::  scrollback buffer and clear the screen, instead of just clearing
2811 | #::  the screen. For ZSH, in ~/.zshrc, add:
2812 | 
2813 | #::  .. code-block:: zsh
2814 | 
2815 | #::      ctrl_l() {
2816 | #::          builtin print -rn -- $'\r\e[0J\e[H\e[22J' >"$TTY"
2817 | #::          builtin zle .reset-prompt
2818 | #::          builtin zle -R
2819 | #::      }
2820 | #::      zle -N ctrl_l
2821 | #::      bindkey '^l' ctrl_l
2822 | 
2823 | #::  Alternatively, you can just add map ctrl+l clear_terminal
2824 | #::  to_cursor_scroll active to kitty.conf which works with no changes
2825 | #::  to the shell rc files, but only clears up to the prompt, it does
2826 | #::  not clear any text at the prompt itself.

2844 | #: Reload kitty.conf

2846 | # map kitty_mod+f5 load_config_file
2847 | # map ctrl+cmd+,   load_config_file
2848 | 
2849 | #::  Reload kitty.conf, applying any changes since the last time it
2850 | #::  was loaded. Note that a handful of options cannot be dynamically
2851 | #::  changed and require a full restart of kitty. Particularly, when
2852 | #::  changing shortcuts for actions located on the macOS global menu
2853 | #::  bar, a full restart is needed. You can also map a keybinding to
2854 | #::  load a different config file, for example::
2855 | 
2856 | #::      map f5 load_config /path/to/alternative/kitty.conf
2857 | 
2858 | #::  Note that all options from the original kitty.conf are discarded,
2859 | #::  in other words the new configuration *replace* the old ones.
2860 |

2862 | 
2863 | # map kitty_mod+f6 debug_config
2864 | # map opt+cmd+,    debug_config

2866 | #::  Show details about exactly what configuration kitty is running
2867 | #::  with and its host environment. Useful for debugging issues.
2868 | 
2869 | #: Send arbitrary text on key presses
2870 | 
2871 | #::  E.g. map ctrl+shift+alt+h send_text all Hello World
2872 | 
2873 | #::  You can tell kitty to send arbitrary (UTF-8) encoded text to the
2874 | #::  client program when pressing specified shortcut keys. For
2875 | #::  example::
2876 | 
2877 | #::      map ctrl+alt+a send_text all Special text
2878 | 
2879 | #::  This will send "Special text" when you press the Ctrl+Alt+A key
2880 | #::  combination. The text to be sent decodes ANSI C escapes
2881 | #::  <https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/ANSI_002dC-
2882 | #::  Quoting.html> so you can use escapes like \e to send control
2883 | #::  codes or \u21fb to send Unicode characters (or you can just input
2884 | #::  the Unicode characters directly as UTF-8 text). You can use
2885 | #::  `kitten show-key` to get the key escape codes you want to
2886 | #::  emulate.
2887 | 
2888 | #::  The first argument to send_text is the keyboard modes in which to
2889 | #::  activate the shortcut. The possible values are normal,
2890 | #::  application, kitty or a comma separated combination of them. The
2891 | #::  modes normal and application refer to the DECCKM cursor key mode
2892 | #::  for terminals, and kitty refers to the kitty extended keyboard
2893 | #::  protocol. The special value all means all of them.
2894 | 
2895 | #::  Some more examples::
2896 | 
2897 | #::      # Output a word and move the cursor to the start of the line (like typing and pressing Home)
2898 | #::      map ctrl+alt+a send_text normal Word\e[H
2899 | #::      map ctrl+alt+a send_text application Word\eOH
2900 | #::      # Run a command at a shell prompt (like typing the command and pressing Enter)

Dựa trên cấu hình hiện tại của bạn (đã có `zsh`, `starship`, `atuin`, `tmux`, `kitty`), mình thấy bạn đã có một nền tảng rất tốt. Tuy nhiên, để "độ" thêm cho ngầu và tiện dụng hơn, mình có vài gợi ý chia theo các nhóm sau:

### 1. Nâng cấp Giao diện (Visuals)
Hiện tại `tmux.conf` của bạn đang dùng mã màu thủ công (có vẻ giống palette của **Catppuccin Mocha**). Để đồng bộ và đẹp hơn:

*   **Đồng bộ Theme:** Hãy áp dụng theme **Catppuccin Mocha** cho cả **Kitty**, **Tmux**, **Starship**, và **Bat**. Điều này tạo cảm giác liền mạch "nguyên khối" rất chuyên nghiệp.
    *   *Kitty:* Bạn có thể tải theme Catppuccin cho Kitty thay vì để comment màu thủ công.
    *   *Tmux:* Cài đặt **Tmux Plugin Manager (TPM)** và dùng plugin `catppuccin/tmux` để status bar đẹp và nhiều tính năng hơn (hiển thị git branch, pin, thời gian...).
*   **Font chữ:** Trong `kitty.conf` bạn đang để `JetBrains Mono`, nhưng trong thư mục `assets/fonts` mình thấy có **CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font** (phiên bản Nerd của Cascadia Code).
    *   *Gợi ý:* Hãy thử đổi sang `CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font` trong `kitty.conf`. Font này hỗ trợ icon tốt hơn cho Starship và Fastfetch, lại có chữ nghiêng (italic) rất đẹp.
*   **Fastfetch:** Bạn đang dùng config mẫu `sample_2.jsonc`. Bạn có thể tạo một file config riêng, thêm logo custom (như file `jedi.png` bạn đang có trong `assets/images`) để mỗi khi mở terminal lên là thấy "chất" riêng.

### 2. Công cụ "Hạng nặng" (Power Tools)
Bạn đã có `atuin` (lịch sử lệnh) và `zsh-autosuggestions`, hãy thêm bộ tứ "thần thánh" này:

*   **Zoxide (`z`):** Thay thế lệnh `cd`. Nó "học" các thư mục bạn hay vào. Thay vì gõ `cd ~/Projects/teminal-custom`, bạn chỉ cần gõ `z term` là nó tự nhảy tới.
*   **Eza (hoặc Lsd):** Thay thế lệnh `ls`. Hiển thị danh sách file với icon, màu sắc phân loại file, và git status ngay bên cạnh.
*   **Bat:** Thay thế lệnh `cat`. Xem nội dung file với syntax highlighting (tô màu code), số dòng và tích hợp git.
*   **FZF (Fuzzy Finder):** Tìm kiếm mờ. Kết hợp với phím tắt `Ctrl+R` (dù Atuin đã làm tốt) hoặc tìm file, kill process cực nhanh.

### 3. Quản lý Git & File
*   **Lazygit:** Một giao diện terminal (TUI) cực mạnh cho Git. Quản lý branch, commit, merge conflict nhanh hơn gõ lệnh rất nhiều.
*   **Yazi (hoặc Ranger):** Trình quản lý file ngay trong terminal. Yazi được viết bằng Rust (rất nhanh), hỗ trợ xem trước ảnh ngay trong terminal (đặc biệt tốt với Kitty).

### 4. Tmux "Bất tử"
*   **Tmux Resurrect & Continuum:** Hiện tại nếu tắt máy, các session Tmux của bạn sẽ mất. Cài 2 plugin này qua TPM sẽ giúp Tmux tự động lưu và khôi phục lại toàn bộ cửa sổ/pane y hệt như trước khi tắt máy.

### Tóm tắt lộ trình "độ":
1.  **Cài đặt TPM** cho Tmux.
2.  **Cài đặt các tool:** `zoxide`, `eza`, `bat`, `fzf`, `lazygit`.
3.  **Sửa `.zshrc`:** Alias lại `ls` thành `eza`, `cat` thành `bat`, và init `zoxide`.
4.  **Chỉnh Theme:** Đồng bộ màu sắc Catppuccin cho toàn hệ thống.

Bạn muốn mình bắt đầu hướng dẫn chi tiết phần nào trước? (Ví dụ: Cài đặt bộ tool Rust hay cấu hình lại Tmux?)

<question>Dựa trên cấu hình hiện tại (đã có `zsh`, `starship`, `atuin`, `tmux`, `kitty`), mình có các gợi ý sau để nâng cấp terminal của bạn. Bạn muốn mình hướng dẫn chi tiết phần nào trước?

1.  **Nâng cấp Giao diện (Visuals):**
    *   **Đồng bộ Theme:** Áp dụng Catppuccin Mocha cho cả Kitty, Tmux, Starship để tạo cảm giác liền mạch.
    *   **Font chữ:** Đổi sang `CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font` (có sẵn trong `assets/fonts`) để hỗ trợ icon tốt hơn và có chữ nghiêng đẹp mắt.
    *   **Fastfetch:** Custom lại config để hiển thị logo riêng (như `jedi.png`) và thông tin gọn gàng hơn.

2.  **Công cụ "Hạng nặng" (Power Tools):**
    *   **Zoxide (`z`):** Thay thế `cd`, tự động nhớ thư mục hay dùng.
    *   **Eza:** Thay thế `ls`, hiển thị icon, màu sắc và git status.
    *   **Bat:** Thay thế `cat`, có syntax highlighting.
    *   **FZF:** Tìm kiếm mờ siêu nhanh.

3.  **Quản lý & Workflow:**
    *   **Lazygit:** Giao diện TUI quản lý Git cực nhanh.
    *   **Yazi:** Trình quản lý file bằng Rust, xem trước ảnh ngay trong terminal.
    *   **Tmux Plugins:** Cài TPM, Resurrect & Continuum để tự động lưu/khôi phục session khi tắt máy.

  1 | #!/bin/bash
  2 | # =============================================================================
  3 | # common.sh - Shared utilities for terminal-custom setup scripts
  4 | # =============================================================================
  5 | 
  6 | # Resolve paths
  7 | SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
  8 | PROJECT_ROOT="$(cd "$SCRIPT_DIR/.." && pwd)"
  9 | BACKUP_DIR="$PROJECT_ROOT/assets"
 10 | 
 11 | # Colors
 12 | RED='\033[0;31m'
 13 | GREEN='\033[0;32m'
 14 | YELLOW='\033[1;33m'
 15 | BLUE='\033[0;34m'
 16 | CYAN='\033[0;36m'
 17 | BOLD='\033[1m'
 18 | NC='\033[0m' # No Color
 19 | 
 20 | # =============================================================================
 21 | # Logging Functions
 22 | # =============================================================================
 23 | 
 24 | log_info() {
 25 |     echo -e "${BLUE}[INFO]${NC} $1"
 26 | }
 27 | 
 28 | log_success() {
 29 |     echo -e "${GREEN}[✓]${NC} $1"
 30 | }
 31 | 
 32 | log_warn() {
 33 |     echo -e "${YELLOW}[!]${NC} $1"
 34 | }
 35 | 
 36 | log_error() {
 37 |     echo -e "${RED}[✗]${NC} $1"
 38 | }
 39 | 
 40 | log_section() {
 41 |     echo ""
 42 |     echo -e "${GREEN}${BOLD}>>> $1${NC}"
 43 | }
 44 | 
 45 | # =============================================================================
 46 | # Utility Functions
 47 | # =============================================================================
 48 | 
 49 | # Create directory if it doesn't exist
 50 | ensure_dir() {
 51 |     local dir="$1"
 52 |     if [[ ! -d "$dir" ]]; then
 53 |         mkdir -p "$dir"
 54 |         log_success "Created directory: $dir"
 55 |     fi
 56 | }
 57 | 
 58 | # Check if a command exists
 59 | check_command() {
 60 |     command -v "$1" &> /dev/null
 61 | }
 62 | 
 63 | # Run command with sudo, non-interactive
 64 | run_sudo() {
 65 |     sudo "$@"
 66 | }
 67 | 
 68 | # Install packages via dnf (non-interactive)
 69 | dnf_install() {
 70 |     sudo dnf install -y "$@"
 71 | }
 72 | 
 73 | # Check if running as root (we don't want that)
 74 | check_not_root() {
 75 |     if [[ $EUID -eq 0 ]]; then
 76 |         log_error "Do not run this script as root. Use a regular user with sudo access."
 77 |         exit 1
 78 |     fi
 79 | }
 80 | 
 81 | # Verify backup directory exists
 82 | verify_backup_dir() {
 83 |     if [[ ! -d "$BACKUP_DIR" ]]; then
 84 |         log_error "Backup directory not found: $BACKUP_DIR"
 85 |         exit 1
 86 |     fi
 87 | }
 88 | 
 89 | # Copy file with backup of existing
 90 | copy_with_backup() {
 91 |     local src="$1"
 92 |     local dest="$2"
 93 |     
 94 |     if [[ -f "$dest" ]]; then
 95 |         cp "$dest" "${dest}.backup.$(date +%Y%m%d%H%M%S)"
 96 |         log_warn "Backed up existing: $dest"
 97 |     fi
 98 |     
 99 |     cp "$src" "$dest"
100 |     log_success "Copied: $src -> $dest"
101 | }
102 | 
103 | # Copy directory recursively
104 | copy_dir() {
105 |     local src="$1"
106 |     local dest="$2"
107 |     
108 |     ensure_dir "$dest"
109 |     cp -r "$src"/* "$dest"/ 2>/dev/null || true
110 |     log_success "Copied directory: $src -> $dest"
111 | }
112 | 
113 | # =============================================================================
114 | # Export for sourcing
115 | # =============================================================================
116 | export SCRIPT_DIR PROJECT_ROOT BACKUP_DIR
117 | export RED GREEN YELLOW BLUE CYAN BOLD NC
</content>

I'll start by creating the enhance_terminal.sh script to install all the power tools:

<write_to_file>
<path>scripts/enhance_terminal.sh</path>
<content>#!/bin/bash
# =============================================================================
# enhance_terminal.sh - Install power tools for enhanced terminal experience
# =============================================================================

set -e

# Source common utilities
SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
source "$SCRIPT_DIR/common.sh"

check_not_root
verify_backup_dir

# =============================================================================
# Install Power Tools via DNF
# =============================================================================
log_section "Installing Power Tools..."

# Tools available in Fedora repos
POWER_TOOLS=(
    zoxide      # Smart cd replacement
    eza         # Modern ls replacement
    bat         # Cat with syntax highlighting
    fzf         # Fuzzy finder
    ripgrep     # Fast grep alternative (useful with fzf)
    fd-find     # Fast find alternative (useful with fzf)
)

log_info "Installing tools from DNF repositories..."
dnf_install "${POWER_TOOLS[@]}"
log_success "DNF tools installed"

# =============================================================================
# Install Lazygit
# =============================================================================
log_section "Installing Lazygit..."

if check_command lazygit; then
    log_success "Lazygit already installed"
else
    # Add Lazygit COPR repository
    if ! sudo dnf copr list | grep -q "atim/lazygit"; then
        log_info "Adding Lazygit COPR repository..."
        sudo dnf copr enable atim/lazygit -y
    fi
    dnf_install lazygit
    log_success "Lazygit installed"
fi

# =============================================================================
# Install Yazi (Terminal File Manager)
# =============================================================================
log_section "Installing Yazi..."

if check_command yazi; then
    log_success "Yazi already installed"
else
    # Yazi is available via cargo or prebuilt binaries
    # Using prebuilt binary for faster installation
    YAZI_VERSION="0.4.2"
    YAZI_URL="https://github.com/sxyazi/yazi/releases/download/v${YAZI_VERSION}/yazi-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu.zip"
    TEMP_DIR=$(mktemp -d)
    
    log_info "Downloading Yazi v${YAZI_VERSION}..."
    curl -sL "$YAZI_URL" -o "$TEMP_DIR/yazi.zip"
    
    log_info "Extracting Yazi..."
    unzip -q "$TEMP_DIR/yazi.zip" -d "$TEMP_DIR"
    
    log_info "Installing Yazi to ~/.local/bin..."
    ensure_dir "$HOME/.local/bin"
    cp "$TEMP_DIR/yazi-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/yazi" "$HOME/.local/bin/"
    cp "$TEMP_DIR/yazi-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/ya" "$HOME/.local/bin/"
    chmod +x "$HOME/.local/bin/yazi" "$HOME/.local/bin/ya"
    
    rm -rf "$TEMP_DIR"
    log_success "Yazi installed"
fi

# =============================================================================
# Install Tmux Plugin Manager (TPM)
# =============================================================================
log_section "Installing Tmux Plugin Manager..."

TPM_DIR="$HOME/.tmux/plugins/tpm"
if [[ -d "$TPM_DIR" ]]; then
    log_success "TPM already installed"
else
    log_info "Cloning TPM..."
    git clone https://github.com/tmux-plugins/tpm "$TPM_DIR"
    log_success "TPM installed"
fi

# =============================================================================
# Copy Enhanced Configurations
# =============================================================================
log_section "Copying enhanced configurations..."

# Copy enhanced .zshrc
if [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.zshrc.enhanced" ]]; then
    cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.zshrc.enhanced" ~/.zshrc
    log_success "Enhanced .zshrc copied"
elif [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.zshrc" ]]; then
    cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.zshrc" ~/.zshrc
    log_success ".zshrc copied (will be enhanced manually)"
fi

# Copy enhanced tmux config
if [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/tmux/tmux.conf.enhanced" ]]; then
    ensure_dir ~/.config/tmux
    cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/tmux/tmux.conf.enhanced" ~/.config/tmux/tmux.conf
    log_success "Enhanced tmux.conf copied"
fi

# Copy enhanced kitty config  
if [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/kitty/kitty.conf.enhanced" ]]; then
    ensure_dir ~/.config/kitty
    cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/kitty/kitty.conf.enhanced" ~/.config/kitty/kitty.conf
    log_success "Enhanced kitty.conf copied"
fi

# Copy Catppuccin theme for kitty if exists
if [[ -f "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/kitty/catppuccin-mocha.conf" ]]; then
    cp "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/kitty/catppuccin-mocha.conf" ~/.config/kitty/
    log_success "Catppuccin theme for kitty copied"
fi

# Copy yazi config if exists
if [[ -d "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/yazi" ]]; then
    copy_dir "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/yazi" ~/.config/yazi
fi

# Copy bat config if exists
if [[ -d "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/bat" ]]; then
    copy_dir "$BACKUP_DIR/.config/bat" ~/.config/bat
fi

# =============================================================================
# Post-installation Setup
# =============================================================================
log_section "Post-installation setup..."

# Build bat cache for themes
if check_command bat; then
    log_info "Building bat theme cache..."
    bat cache --build 2>/dev/null || true
    log_success "Bat cache built"
fi

# Initialize zoxide database
if check_command zoxide; then
    log_info "Zoxide will initialize on first use"
fi

# =============================================================================
# Instructions
# =============================================================================
log_section "Enhancement complete!"

echo ""
echo -e "${CYAN}${BOLD}Next steps:${NC}"
echo ""
echo "1. Restart your terminal or run: source ~/.zshrc"
echo ""
echo "2. Install tmux plugins by pressing: Ctrl+a then I (capital i)"
echo "   (This will install Catppuccin theme and session plugins)"
echo ""
echo "3. New aliases available:"
echo "   - ls  → eza (with icons and colors)"
echo "   - ll  → eza -la (detailed list)"
echo "   - lt  → eza --tree (tree view)"
echo "   - cat → bat (syntax highlighting)"
echo "   - cd  → z (smart directory jumping)"
echo "   - lg  → lazygit"
echo "   - y   → yazi (file manager)"
echo ""
echo "4. FZF keybindings:"
echo "   - Ctrl+R → Search command history"
echo "   - Ctrl+T → Search files"
echo "   - Alt+C  → cd to directory"
echo ""
</content>

content.text:
Now let me create the enhanced .zshrc with all the tool integrations:

<write_to_file>
<path>assets/.zshrc.enhanced</path>
<content># =============================================================================
# Enhanced Zsh Configuration
# =============================================================================

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Starship Prompt
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
eval "$(starship init zsh)"

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Zsh Plugins
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Try system-wide first, then fall back to local installation
if [[ -f /usr/share/zsh-autosuggestions/zsh-autosuggestions.zsh ]]; then
    source /usr/share/zsh-autosuggestions/zsh-autosuggestions.zsh
elif [[ -f ~/.local/share/zsh/plugins/zsh-autosuggestions/zsh-autosuggestions.zsh ]]; then
    source ~/.local/share/zsh/plugins/zsh-autosuggestions/zsh-autosuggestions.zsh
fi

if [[ -f /usr/share/zsh-syntax-highlighting/zsh-syntax-highlighting.zsh ]]; then
    source /usr/share/zsh-syntax-highlighting/zsh-syntax-highlighting.zsh
elif [[ -f ~/.local/share/zsh/plugins/zsh-syntax-highlighting/zsh-syntax-highlighting.zsh ]]; then
    source ~/.local/share/zsh/plugins/zsh-syntax-highlighting/zsh-syntax-highlighting.zsh
fi

if [[ -f /usr/share/zsh-autocomplete/zsh-autocomplete.plugin.zsh ]]; then
    source /usr/share/zsh-autocomplete/zsh-autocomplete.plugin.zsh
elif [[ -f ~/.local/share/zsh/plugins/zsh-autocomplete/zsh-autocomplete.plugin.zsh ]]; then
    source ~/.local/share/zsh/plugins/zsh-autocomplete/zsh-autocomplete.plugin.zsh
fi

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Atuin (Shell History)
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
if [[ -f "$HOME/.atuin/bin/env" ]]; then
    . "$HOME/.atuin/bin/env"
    eval "$(atuin init zsh)"
fi

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Path Configuration
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$HOME/bin:$PATH"

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Zoxide (Smart cd)
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
if command -v zoxide &> /dev/null; then
    eval "$(zoxide init zsh)"
fi

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# FZF (Fuzzy Finder)
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
if command -v fzf &> /dev/null; then
    # FZF key bindings and completion
    if [[ -f /usr/share/fzf/shell/key-bindings.zsh ]]; then
        source /usr/share/fzf/shell/key-bindings.zsh
    fi
    
    # Catppuccin Mocha theme for FZF
    export FZF_DEFAULT_OPTS=" \
        --color=bg+:#313244,bg:#1e1e2e,spinner:#f5e0dc,hl:#f38ba8 \
        --color=fg:#cdd6f4,header:#f38ba8,info:#cba6f7,pointer:#f5e0dc \
        --color=marker:#b4befe,fg+:#cdd6f4,prompt:#cba6f7,hl+:#f38ba8 \
        --color=selected-bg:#45475a \
        --multi"
    
    # Use fd for file searching if available (faster than find)
    if command -v fd &> /dev/null; then
        export FZF_DEFAULT_COMMAND='fd --type f --hidden --follow --exclude .git'
        export FZF_CTRL_T_COMMAND="$FZF_DEFAULT_COMMAND"
        export FZF_ALT_C_COMMAND='fd --type d --hidden --follow --exclude .git'
    fi
fi

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Eza (Modern ls)
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
if command -v eza &> /dev/null; then
    alias ls='eza --icons --group-directories-first'
    alias ll='eza -la --icons --group-directories-first --git'
    alias la='eza -a --icons --group-directories-first'
    alias lt='eza --tree --icons --level=2'
    alias lta='eza --tree --icons --level=2 -a'
    alias l='eza -l --icons --group-directories-first'
else
    alias ll='ls -la'
    alias la='ls -a'
    alias l='ls -l'
fi

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Bat (Modern cat)
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
if command -v bat &> /dev/null; then
    alias cat='bat --paging=never'
    alias catp='bat'  # with paging
    export MANPAGER="sh -c 'col -bx | bat -l man -p'"
    export BAT_THEME="Catppuccin Mocha"
fi

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Application Aliases
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Lazygit
if command -v lazygit &> /dev/null; then
    alias lg='lazygit'
fi

# Yazi file manager with directory change on exit
if command -v yazi &> /dev/null; then
    function y() {
        local tmp="$(mktemp -t "yazi-cwd.XXXXXX")" cwd
        yazi "$@" --cwd-file="$tmp"
        if cwd="$(command cat -- "$tmp")" && [ -n "$cwd" ] && [ "$cwd" != "$PWD" ]; then
            builtin cd -- "$cwd"
        fi
        rm -f -- "$tmp"
    }
fi

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Useful Aliases
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Git shortcuts
alias g='git'
alias gs='git status'
alias ga='git add'
alias gc='git commit'
alias gp='git push'
alias gl='git pull'
alias gd='git diff'
alias gco='git checkout'
alias gb='git branch'
alias glog='git log --oneline --graph --decorate'

# Directory navigation
alias ..='cd ..'
alias ...='cd ../..'
alias ....='cd ../../..'

# Safety nets
alias rm='rm -i'
alias cp='cp -i'
alias mv='mv -i'

# Misc
alias cls='clear'
alias h='history'
alias grep='grep --color=auto'
alias df='df -h'
alias du='du -h'
alias free='free -h'

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Custom Functions
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Create directory and cd into it
mkcd() {
    mkdir -p "$1" && cd "$1"
}

# Extract various archive formats
extract() {
    if [[ -f "$1" ]]; then
        case "$1" in
            *.tar.bz2)   tar xjf "$1"     ;;
            *.tar.gz)    tar xzf "$1"     ;;
            *.tar.xz)    tar xJf "$1"     ;;
            *.bz2)       bunzip2 "$1"     ;;
            *.rar)       unrar x "$1"     ;;
            *.gz)        gunzip "$1"      ;;
            *.tar)       tar xf "$1"      ;;
            *.tbz2)      tar xjf "$1"     ;;
            *.tgz)       tar xzf "$1"     ;;
            *.zip)       unzip "$1"       ;;
            *.Z)         uncompress "$1"  ;;
            *.7z)        7z x "$1"        ;;
            *)           echo "'$1' cannot be extracted via extract()" ;;
        esac
    else
        echo "'$1' is not a valid file"
    fi
}

# Quick find
qf() {
    find . -name "*$1*" 2>/dev/null
}

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Fastfetch (System Info on Terminal Start)
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
if command -v fastfetch &> /dev/null; then
    fastfetch -c ~/.config/fastfetch/sample_2.jsonc
fi

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Zsh Options
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
setopt AUTO_CD              # cd by typing directory name
setopt AUTO_PUSHD           # Push directories to stack
setopt PUSHD_IGNORE_DUPS    # Don't push duplicates
setopt CORRECT              # Spell correction for commands
setopt EXTENDED_GLOB        # Extended globbing
setopt NO_BEEP              # Disable beep

# History options
HISTSIZE=50000
SAVEHIST=50000
HISTFILE=~/.zsh_history
setopt SHARE_HISTORY        # Share history between sessions
setopt HIST_IGNORE_DUPS     # Ignore duplicate commands
setopt HIST_IGNORE_SPACE    # Ignore commands starting with space
setopt HIST_REDUCE_BLANKS   # Remove extra blanks

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Completion Settings
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
autoload -Uz compinit
compinit

zstyle ':completion:*' menu select
zstyle ':completion:*' matcher-list 'm:{a-zA-Z}={A-Za-z}'  # Case-insensitive
zstyle ':completion:*' list-colors "${(s.:.)LS_COLORS}"    # Colored completion

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Key Bindings
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
bindkey -e                          # Emacs keybindings
bindkey '^[[A' history-search-backward
bindkey '^[[B' history-search-forward
bindkey '^[[H' beginning-of-line    # Home key
bindkey '^[[F' end-of-line          # End key
bindkey '^[[3~' delete-char         # Delete key
</content>

content.text:
Now let me create the enhanced kitty.conf with CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font and Catppuccin theme:

<write_to_file>
<path>assets/.config/kitty/kitty.conf.enhanced</path>
<content># =============================================================================
# Enhanced Kitty Configuration
# =============================================================================

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Include Catppuccin Theme
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
include catppuccin-mocha.conf

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Fonts
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
font_family      CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font
bold_font        CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font Bold
italic_font      CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font Italic
bold_italic_font CaskaydiaCove Nerd Font Bold Italic
font_size 14.0

# Enable font ligatures
disable_ligatures never

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Cursor
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
cursor_shape block
cursor_blink_interval 0.5
cursor_stop_blinking_after 15.0

# Cursor trail effect (cool visual)
cursor_trail 100
cursor_trail_decay 0.1 0.4
cursor_trail_start_threshold 2

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Scrollback
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
scrollback_lines 10000
scrollback_pager less --chop-long-lines --RAW-CONTROL-CHARS +INPUT_LINE_NUMBER

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Mouse
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
mouse_hide_wait 3.0
url_style curly
open_url_with default
detect_urls yes
copy_on_select clipboard

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Performance
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
repaint_delay 10
input_delay 3
sync_to_monitor yes

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Terminal Bell
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
enable_audio_bell no
visual_bell_duration 0.0
window_alert_on_bell yes
bell_on_tab "🔔 "

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Window Layout
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
remember_window_size  no
initial_window_width  120c
initial_window_height 30c

window_padding_width 8
single_window_padding_width 8

placement_strategy center
hide_window_decorations no

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Tab Bar
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
tab_bar_edge bottom
tab_bar_style powerline
tab_powerline_style round
tab_bar_min_tabs 1

tab_title_template "{fmt.fg.red}{bell_symbol}{activity_symbol}{fmt.fg.tab}{index}: {title}"
active_tab_title_template "{fmt.fg._cba6f7}{bell_symbol}{activity_symbol}{fmt.fg.tab}{index}: {title}"

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Background
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
background_opacity 0.85
dynamic_background_opacity yes
background_blur 32

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Advanced
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
shell /usr/bin/zsh
editor nvim
allow_remote_control socket-only
listen_on unix:/tmp/kitty
shell_integration enabled

# Clipboard
clipboard_control write-clipboard write-primary read-clipboard-ask read-primary-ask
clipboard_max_size 512

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Keyboard Shortcuts
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
kitty_mod ctrl+shift

# Clipboard
map kitty_mod+c copy_to_clipboard
map kitty_mod+v paste_from_clipboard

# Font size
map kitty_mod+equal change_font_size all +2.0
map kitty_mod+minus change_font_size all -2.0
map kitty_mod+backspace change_font_size all 0

# Window management
map kitty_mod+enter new_window_with_cwd
map kitty_mod+n new_os_window_with_cwd
map kitty_mod+w close_window
map kitty_mod+] next_window
map kitty_mod+[ previous_window

# Tab management
map kitty_mod+t new_tab_with_cwd
map kitty_mod+q close_tab
map kitty_mod+right next_tab
map kitty_mod+left previous_tab
map kitty_mod+. move_tab_forward
map kitty_mod+, move_tab_backward

# Layout
map kitty_mod+l next_layout

# Scrollback
map kitty_mod+k scroll_line_up
map kitty_mod+j scroll_line_down
map kitty_mod+page_up scroll_page_up
map kitty_mod+page_down scroll_page_down
map kitty_mod+home scroll_home
map kitty_mod+end scroll_end
map kitty_mod+h show_scrollback

# Hints (for selecting URLs, files, etc.)
map kitty_mod+e open_url_with_hints
map kitty_mod+p>f kitten hints --type path --program -
map kitty_mod+p>l kitten hints --type line --program -
map kitty_mod+p>w kitten hints --type word --program -

# Background opacity
map kitty_mod+a>m set_background_opacity +0.1
map kitty_mod+a>l set_background_opacity -0.1
map kitty_mod+a>1 set_background_opacity 1
map kitty_mod+a>d set_background_opacity default

# Misc
map kitty_mod+f11 toggle_fullscreen
map kitty_mod+f10 toggle_maximized
map kitty_mod+u kitten unicode_input
map kitty_mod+f2 edit_config_file
map kitty_mod+f5 load_config_file
map kitty_mod+f6 debug_config

# Quick actions
map ctrl+shift+g kitten hints --type=linenum --linenum-action=tab nvim +{line} {path}
</content>
<line_count>160</line_count>
</write_to_file>

content.text:
Now let me create the enhanced tmux.conf with TPM, Catppuccin theme, and Resurrect/Continuum:

<write_to_file>
<path>assets/.config/tmux/tmux.conf.enhanced</path>
<content># =============================================================================
# Enhanced tmux Configuration with TPM and Catppuccin
# =============================================================================

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# General Settings
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Enable true color support
set -g default-terminal "tmux-256color"
set -ga terminal-overrides ",*256col*:Tc"
set -ga terminal-overrides ",xterm-kitty:Tc"

# Enable mouse support
set -g mouse on

# Start windows and panes at 1, not 0
set -g base-index 1
setw -g pane-base-index 1

# Renumber windows when one is closed
set -g renumber-windows on

# Increase history limit
set -g history-limit 50000

# Faster key repetition
set -s escape-time 0

# Enable focus events
set -g focus-events on

# Aggressive resize
setw -g aggressive-resize on

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Key Bindings
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Change prefix to Ctrl-a (more ergonomic than Ctrl-b)
unbind C-b
set -g prefix C-a
bind C-a send-prefix

# Reload config
bind r source-file ~/.config/tmux/tmux.conf \; display "Config reloaded!"

# Split panes using | and -
bind | split-window -h -c "#{pane_current_path}"
bind - split-window -v -c "#{pane_current_path}"
unbind '"'
unbind %

# Navigate panes with vim keys
bind h select-pane -L
bind j select-pane -D
bind k select-pane -U
bind l select-pane -R

# Resize panes with vim keys
bind -r H resize-pane -L 5
bind -r J resize-pane -D 5
bind -r K resize-pane -U 5
bind -r L resize-pane -R 5

# New window in current path
bind c new-window -c "#{pane_current_path}"

# Quick window selection
bind -r C-h select-window -t :-
bind -r C-l select-window -t :+

# Swap windows
bind -r "<" swap-window -d -t -1
bind -r ">" swap-window -d -t +1

# Toggle last window
bind Space last-window

# Synchronize panes
bind S setw synchronize-panes

# Kill pane/window without confirmation
bind x kill-pane
bind X kill-window

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Copy Mode (Vi style)
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

setw -g mode-keys vi
bind -T copy-mode-vi v send -X begin-selection
bind -T copy-mode-vi y send -X copy-pipe-and-cancel 'xclip -in -selection clipboard'
bind -T copy-mode-vi C-v send -X rectangle-toggle
bind -T copy-mode-vi Escape send -X cancel

# Enter copy mode with Ctrl-a [
bind [ copy-mode
bind ] paste-buffer

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Session Management
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Create new session
bind N new-session

# Switch sessions with fzf (if available)
bind s choose-tree -Zs

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Catppuccin Theme Configuration
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

set -g @catppuccin_flavor 'mocha'
set -g @catppuccin_window_status_style "rounded"

# Window styling
set -g @catppuccin_window_number_position "left"
set -g @catppuccin_window_default_fill "number"
set -g @catppuccin_window_default_text "#W"
set -g @catppuccin_window_current_fill "number"
set -g @catppuccin_window_current_text "#W"

# Status bar modules
set -g @catppuccin_status_modules_right "directory session date_time"
set -g @catppuccin_status_modules_left ""
set -g @catppuccin_status_left_separator  ""
set -g @catppuccin_status_right_separator " "
set -g @catppuccin_status_fill "all"
set -g @catppuccin_status_connect_separator "yes"

# Date/time format
set -g @catppuccin_date_time_text "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M"

# Directory
set -g @catppuccin_directory_text "#{pane_current_path}"

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Resurrect & Continuum Settings
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Resurrect settings
set -g @resurrect-capture-pane-contents 'on'
set -g @resurrect-strategy-nvim 'session'
set -g @resurrect-strategy-vim 'session'

# Continuum settings
set -g @continuum-restore 'on'
set -g @continuum-save-interval '15'

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Status Bar Position
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
set -g status-position bottom
set -g status-interval 5

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Pane Borders (Catppuccin colors)
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
set -g pane-border-style 'fg=#45475a'
set -g pane-active-border-style 'fg=#89b4fa'

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Message Style (Catppuccin colors)
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
set -g message-style 'bg=#313244 fg=#cdd6f4'

# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Tmux Plugin Manager (TPM)
# -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

# List of plugins
set -g @plugin 'tmux-plugins/tpm'
set -g @plugin 'tmux-plugins/tmux-sensible'
set -g @plugin 'catppuccin/tmux#v2.1.0'
set -g @plugin 'tmux-plugins/tmux-resurrect'
set -g @plugin 'tmux-plugins/tmux-continuum'
set -g @plugin 'tmux-plugins/tmux-yank'

# Initialize TMUX plugin manager (keep this line at the very bottom of tmux.conf)
run '~/.tmux/plugins/tpm/tpm'
</content>
